column10: lego dream come true. need more enviromental additions but overall great game!

this is one of the games i watched YouTubers play back then and thought "man i'd love to play that." years later i finally get the chance to properly play it.

as expected, the sandbox vehicle customization and block-based system is very appealing, able to make vehicles of all shapes and sizes for differing purposes. it is very satisfying to be able to beat Techs that daunted you beforehand and getting new weapons that give you the edge in combat. before you know it you have this giant land battleship that trivializes most fights which is a great feeling. you don't even need to build a giant land rover, making cool and unique Techs can give a food feeling when you see things click together.

outside of travel, being able to make Techs that interact with the various resources you get or just be used for purposes outside travel and combat is also satisfying. being able to send giant batches of resources for BB or making an overarching black hole block storage is cool. 

however towards the end the game shows its flaws towards the end because frankly there isn't much to do. you unlock all the licenses of the various Corps and probably max them out, you have a grasp on resource collection and combat, and that is it. there are no end game missions that really challenge you or anything. heck, by maxing the license of a Corp, you can buy parts from them immediately without hardship.

i love going to battle with my big Tech, and it just never gets the chance to flex anymore since everything dies in one or two volleys. like, give me a mission to take down a supergiant Tech or a fleet of larger tryhard Techs or something. that'd be sick.

outside of the end game being lacking, there are a few nitpicks i feel need quality of life fixes. 
- a lack of a block and resource encyclopedia (the resource one in particular because i don't know where a certain resource's biome is, and that's important for fabrication and quests), 
- not being able to move a set combination of parts because doing so just leads to the structure collapsing, 
- no proper tutorial for hovercraft/aircraft making which makes building a chore and needing external resources, 
- big techs causing giant messes with resources you're not gonna pick up all over the place, just a giant laggy mess,
- most terrains having peaks and troughs which makes travel annoying (some biomes are expected but i feel the grassy areas can be a little flatter),
- at some point the missions feel like a chore especially for license maxing.

i enjoyed the game, i finally got to play a game i liked to watch years back, but its issues are notable. i hope TerraTech Worlds builds on what TerraTech does great, and makes the overall experience smoother and more fun.

For a game, which had been in public development for 10 years and which had it’s 1.0 release 5 years ago, this game is surprisingly bad polished:
- pretty unintuitive UI
- lack of stats for parts, like weight or fire power
- unnecessary interactions (like clicking the radar tower on a BB station to uncover the map), i see no reason why the area is not uncovered automatically, when im close to the stain
- the block rotation is ridiculous random and frustrating
- half implemented controller support, DESPITE they already released the game on consoles
- and the very bad basebuiling, oh boy.  Remove one conveyor brick and your base turns into two separate bases and you have NO freaking chance to reconnect them, you can only rebuild your base. Players reported this 2018, and there is still no so solution for this this. What the h*ll!?!

And these are only the bigger issues of the game…
This was incredibly fun. Campaign: Start with a basic mech, craft, buy, or salvage components from enemies. Level up, explore different families of techs/mechs, build, gather/mine, etc. Great game.

Lego combat, lego production, lego vehicles. It sounds like a match made in heaven right?

It is. But building things is hindered severely by the repressive camera angles. Loading vehicles requires some, but not all, parts to be in your inventory which leads to frustrating inability to switch to your favorite vehicle sometimes. Bad instructions. Controls are bad. Farming is frustrating with the collection system. Building machines is even worse with the camera restrictions. And then a random vehicle spawns RIGHT when you're about to do something big and destroys the base you built. 

The game is really interesting. I like the concept, I like how it balloons into something that I want to spend hours in, designing cool stuff. But I just can't recommend when all these tiny roadblocks keep nipping at my ankles. I came here to build something, and 90% of my time is spent putting out fires only to discover I can't do the thing I was wanting to do all that time ago. For as long as this game has been in development, it's frustrating that the cool ideas they have and the success it has achieved hasn't allowed a more competent interface to be created. Until then, it's hard to get to the fun parts.

I love the premise of the game. The building system isn't too complex and it's not hard to get started. However, the combat system ruins everything for me. It's just not fun at all. Most starter weapons have an insanely tiny range, so you have to be next to the enemies to hit them, leading to no variety. You just autolock and hold space until they die. You don't have to aim, no movement tactics, dodging or anything like that. Just mindless space holding. There are weapons with better range and other items that can add some variety, but the intial combat is not fun at all. 
Another aspect I dislike is the whole tech system, where you can save your techs, despawn and spawn them back. Instead of saving the techs themselves, you just take their snaphots, and despawning them just means returning their blocks to the inventory without reserving them, and to spawn them back you need to have all of the required blocks, so it's possible to just not have the needed blocks and being unable to spawn the tech you need. It's just inconvenient.
I initally got this game as a singleplayer alternative to Robocraft without any free to play issues, and Terratech would be exactly that if not for the problems described. Most of it is just my preferences, but the combat system feels the biggest actual issue and a major letdown. I still like seeing the game develop and a sequel coming out

Feels more like a tech demo than a completed game.  There are [i]massive[/i] usability issues, to the point that I consider this game unfinished.

As one example, the first mission is to find a trading station.  Once we found it, the quest didn't complete.  My brother and I tried everything, but couldn't figure out what to do and had to google it.  The solution is to press right-click(!?) on a tiny part of the of the building which doesn't really stand out. The game gives you no indication of this.

As another example, to take off parts and put them into your inventory, you need to enter building mode, drag the items off your car and onto the ground, leave building mode, drive over the items, then enter building mode again and you'll see them in the inventory.  If there is a simpler way, I wasn't able to find it by either experimentation nor googling.

If you're looking for a good "build vehicles to fight stuff" game, play [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/301520/Robocraft/]Robocraft[/url] instead. If you want to build vehicles and explore, play [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/585420/Trailmakers/]Trailmakers[/url].

The game has to many bugs. NPCs disappear and other times, when reaching the mission location, there are no NPCs at all. It is sad, considering the potential of this game. I also cannot speak in favor of the developers, who push "new game features" such as the "space junkers" rather then fixing what they already have done. Because of the endless bugs, this game is extremely frustrating; and because of the time the developers had to fix this issues and they did not, I will never buy another game from the same developers. That's how it goes: the trash is thrown in the garbage.

[edit]
WARNING: There is a bug which makes techs completely disappear. Based on my experience and other complaints dating back to 2017, it seems to be prone to happening when you are very far from techs. They can still show up on the map and minimap, but the blocks will be gone and the thumbnail in the tech manager will be blank. I would recommend checking the tech manager frequently and always maintaining some backup saves which are confirmed to have all techs in tact. This game-breaking bug has existed for several years and can cost a LOT of time.
[/edit]

I had lots of fun playing this. It's far less complex than Besiege. It's also easier to just get into and have fun. The campaign was fun, but eventually it does feel like it just drops out. No more progress, no big significant end accomplishment. Just "okay, I've unlocked everything now", and the continued ability to do generic missions, fight techs, and build stuff.

I think the game could be a lot more. But it's a great game as it is. I never played multiplayer, as I only saw a few co-op games going when I looked.

For the Linux crew: My entire play time is on Linux. Runs very well. But like it does in Windows, it will bog down when loading as you approach a base with a lot of machines.

Update:
This game is still loads of fun. I can spend hours building new techs and testing them out. Some of the recently added content is great too.

If any of the devs happen to read this: Please work out a deal with the dev who made the Greentech Corporation mod. I would spend another $20 for Greentech Corp DLC. I was only able to play a broken version of it, as some of the dependencies crash the game without fail on Linux. But even the broken version was a lot of fun to explore and build with. Adding it as official DLC with incorporation into the story would be absolutely amazing.

Recommend, with reservations.

Cons:
There's no free camera mode and if you've built up your vehicle to be fairly large, any type of building after on a base becomes a pain in the rear, not fun.
The inventory system is needlessly complicated.  There's no way to even put things in inventory until later in the game, so at a good part of the start you only have these "magnet" modules which make annoying sounds and have things dangling off of them.

Some of the modules have larger hitboxes than they should, making placement a chore.  Sometimes the snap-to system doesn't seem to work that well for recessed surfaces.  Early in the game you'll be juggling batteries and solar panel towers quite a bit each time your vehicle runs out of energy for the repair systems and shields.

Pros:
Large number of items you can build with, has a campaign, you can pick items off enemy vehicles you've destroyed / anything remaining.  Repair system is easy to use.

I'd say it's a pretty good game. Figure I'll play it for a couple dozen hours at least. If you can get it on sale, I'd say it's definitely worth at least checking out. Occasionally gets a bit frustrating when you click the wrong thing and your build falls apart, but there's usually an undo button when that happens.

TerraTech!

This is a cute little game made for people who really like building LEGO. Since that's basically how it works. You snap pieces together into whatever you can think of. Like hovering tanks with jets. Or goofy-looking cars with auto-targeting missiles. Or a massive tank-treaded behemoth with an ungodly amount of firepower, casting a mile-long shadow over once-peaceful grassy plains.

You start as a scrawny cart with maybe one or two guns, beating up enemy Techs your size and hastily taking their lunch money.

As you destroy more rival Techs, you'll collect the blocks they drop, using them to augment yourself into a perfect killing machine. Missions and building factories will also net you some cool stuff.

Alternatively you can play in creative mode/the R&D Labs DLC, which are both fun experiences that give you the chance to build anything you want.

The game has modding support, ranging from skins to brand-new blocks, weapons, and even more game-changing stuff! (Note: for some mods, you'll need to install an external modloader, but it's a very quick process.)

And, the best part?

From today to February 18th, it's only $4.99/$6.39 with the R&D labs DLC, on sale!

I would definitely recommend buying TerraTech if you or a relative love building games/LEGO. Since there's online co-op, too!

My previous review for this game was negative, and for good reasons.
They abandoned the game for a bit over 2 years, multiplayer was a mess, bugs were rampant, and the game ran out of content 30hours in. However, most of these concerns are now gone.

Even though this game was fully released in 2018, there now are consistent updates, the game is almost always on a really good sale, multiplayer has been (ALMOST) fully fixed, and there is a bunch of new content that makes the game that much more vibrant.

Apparently, Payload Studios is working on a sequel and it looks pretty good. The fact they are both making a sequel which is planned to be released this year while updating TerraTech shows their devotion to the series.

To anyone who wants an amazing game to get addicted to for a week straight, this is the game. Whether you are playing with friends or by yourself, you will have a blast, especially knowing the game is ONLY $5 right now.

At first, I wasn't having fun. I couldn't build anything that I liked because I didn't have the blocks, I couldn't make blocks, I couldn't make enough money to buy many blocks, the blocks available to buy were very limited, travelling from one shop to another, searching for blocks was not fun since I didn't have a nice vehicle, there was no point collecting resources because I couldn't do anything with them, all I could do was put a junky craft together out of scraps and try to do quests.

I pushed through.

Once I had maxed GeoCorp license and thus the ability to easily make unlimited money from selling chunks and the ability to buy any GeoCorp block, I started to have fun. However.

There was no point where i felt the need to craft any parts.

It is disappointing that factories and miners etc do not operate once the player is over 600m away.

There is no info about blocks, weapon damage, block weight, wheel weight capacity, wheel max speed, aero block lift, battery capacity, power production rate, wheel steering angle, thrust and wheel propulsion, wheel grip, shield power drain rate, not even block HP, there are damage types but no mention of what is weak or strong against those types.

I encountered multiple game crashes while building and there seems to be no auto-save in creative.

Having too many lights can cause low frame rate.

TerraTech is a game about making cool vehicles, exploring, and blowing up your enemies with huge guns; there is endless room for customization and creativity. I personally found it very enjoyable, and certainly worth the money. However, the exploration isn't particularly interesting - the only real difference between biomes is how annoying the terrain is and what resources there are, the game isn't particularly hard, and I found the controls of the flying vehicles and the mechanics of the hovering vehicles to be entirely unfun. The game is good, but it suffers from several flaws, and there is a sequel coming out.

[h1]A mile wide, an inch deep.[/h1]

As much as I enjoy building vehicles and trying out new tech, it all feels so damn pointless..

There is no endgame, no real goal to work towards other than unlocking new tech, and the devs have made it clear they have no interest in adding any endgame.

Sure, sandbox games can be cool but the problem is the lack of depth in this game. There is really only two things you can do: Mine the same few resources - which is pointless, as you can eventually just buy all the tech ... not that it makes a real difference in how you build anyway though.
Or shoot enemies. Which becomes boring really fast, as the AI is dumb as a rock and your vehicles become so overpowered so fast they pose no real threat to you anymore.
That's it. Nothing more to work towards. And even the few mods can't really change that.

I guess if you get this on a 50+% sale and you can play it with a friend, it can be worth it for some hours.
Unless you are one of those people who enjoy pure sandbox gameplay, although I would say other blocky vehicle building games like Terratech are a better choice, as they have more varied and more complex building options.

Or wait for Terratech 2, which is supposedly coming out "soon" and will (hopefully) have lots of improvements over this.

Fun game! However, over the past 6 years and as of last year, I cannot suggest this game to anyone anymore. Why's that? Payload Studios is releasing a "Updated" version of this game. There is no reason for them to make another game and have this continually supported once their newer game goes live. So it is clear Terratech Worlds is the game we'll be playing in the near future.

I bought this game way back then and played it for some time, maybe less than I should've but I've always reached that pinnacle of accomplishment, built bases, ran lines of machinery to make random junk that fueled my massive techs to dominate opposing techs. Usually every major update because the experience of something new was fun to me. I wasted a good deal of time and enjoyed every moment of it, the best kind of "Waste of time" as anyone who's familiar with the block-building vehicular combat genre will be spending hours of their time making their favorite machine.

Sadly, there's no reason for me to suggest anyone to get this title with Terratech Worlds on the horizon. I'd highly recommend waiting for that as it comes closer to public release or Early Access. If you don't mind wasting money on this anyways and need a itch to be scratched, then this'll do it until that point.

So, turns out this was basically a demo/prelude for the next game, that's why it was basically abandoned and turned into a DLC skin farm.

I recommend the game but only for a few hours of fun, but 10 hours in you're invincible and have everything, and nothing will ever change. Buy it on sale and don't bother with any skins DLC, they really aren't worth it.
Yes, the skin packs helped fund "TerraTech Worlds", but it looks like a graphically better, stripped down version of TerraTech from 2014/15. So I have to ask, will that too be abandoned after 5 years in Early Access and then 1-3 years full release on Steam too?

I got almost a thousand hours in TerraTech, there isn't anything I don't know about it... but it quite simply isn't finished and with Worlds announced... it never will be. So there's one hell of a sting there.

Comments are open and welcome, but if Payload see this, I want to be proven wrong in TerraTech Worlds, it's on my wishlist, but you've dented my hopes for a finished game with how you treated TerraTech.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

[OLD REVIEW] So why is this review negative? Because the game is broken. The game has been broken for years. Depending on the bug you get depends on wether your game save is completely bricked or not.

After 40 hours, my main storyline quest wasn't able to be handed in. i then spent another 10 hours in game and many more trawling online only to find out that if reloading your save doesn't fix it (it didnt) then your just screwed. 

I could restart i guess, i enjoyed the first 40 hours- but i'm one of those people that doesn't enjoy doing the exact same thing again only to get back to the exact same place i was at only to risk the exact same thing happening. [OLD REVIEW ENDS]

If you've read this far, discard everything i wrote above. I'm only leaving it in as a testament to both what happened, and the response to what happened. Shortly after making this review a dev contacted me, fixed my issue and i'm about to go spend far too much more time playing. This isn't one of those games where the devs release then forget about. These aren't the sort of devs that ignore their community.

These are the sort of game creators that care, actively, and will work on making sure you can continue to enjoy your product. The response to me in fixing my problem was quick and professional despite them working on a new game. If you want to support game devs that make good games while actively making sure their IP's are both playable, working and enjoyable then you should buy this.

If you have any problems like i did, please contact the Terratech team via email or any other method that they have set up to solve our problems. They will do everything they can to fix it for you.

It's one of those base-building+fighting games. An offshoot of survivalcraft genre, where tracking your body's metrics is replaced with production lines and automation.

In this game you have a giant repetitive open world with a patchwork of the same biomes. Each feels big in the beginning, when your vehicle is the size of an ant, but in a flying end-game minecrawler you can fly over biomes very fast. Yet i've never reached the end of the world, even on a 700 km/h rocket it was taking too much time.

You pilot a vehicle and fight bots, randomly pulled from the cloud of user-generated cars and dropped not far from you. I never saw user-made planes, choppers or bases. When you destroy enemy's cabs the surviving parts fall off and you can attach them to your RoboCraft-Crossout monstrositat right in the field with no pause like in Captain Forever Remix. Thankfully without a time limit. But with a possibility of a similar pressure — another bot can spawn in range and start attacking.

The combat mechanic is basically absent — you can shoot or not. All guns have auto-aim with extreme bullet drop. It seems the mortars are very popular judging by all the user-generated cars driven by bots. But they are so short-ranged my main car was destroying everything before getting damaged. Even the starting lasers have a very long range and then you unlock missiles.

The assembling GUI is really bad. It's giant, with no scaling options, the controls are bad. I literally couldn't see most of anything when the building GUI was open. And you can't do anything without keeping it open. When you attach parts you roughly aim at a highlighted free connector on the vehicle and press [next] or [previous] while the game tries each and every combination of the part's connectors and rotations. And some parts have hundreds of connectors, each with four rotations. Genius. What was wrong with the industry-standard method of picking the connector and then rotating the part in three axiis? And it all is done from the unwieldy camera's PoV. So you also have to aim the connector at a connector from either too far away, or from up too close, with some things obstructing the view of other things. And then there are parts which plain do not work. Like pivots and axles.

== missing chunk ==

The achievements work fine. They are of different interestingness. The one which asks to make a ton of money is a boring grindathon. Moneymaking is not that fast in best of times. Your mining-refining-selling rigs don't work out of sight. Your minecrawler is not that fast. Even if you reach the flat biome with the most expensive materials — the surface has pittance. Constant fighting can force you to spend money on repairs. When you are trying to build a vehicle for some of the non-combat quests — some giant bots are constantly spawning to pester you. When you drive a scrapper to turn your foes into cash — only tiny cars are spawned. And going against an invasion vehicle can rarely leave you unscathed. Only giant choppers and planes can usually be out of their reach, but they take a lot of time to destroy just one invader. Quest rewards are not that big and they usually send you on 9 km long hikes through mountains.

This old-ish game has bugs, and they are on rotation. The patches still come out, and every-time they fix one thing the other breaks. When i've reached mid-game they've released a patch which makes the button "load game" to have a 60% chance to start a new game instead. With an unskippable long cutscene. As i mentioned, at first conveyors were crashing the game. And some block plain do not work. The game has very bad performance even on medium settings on my 10900k 32 RAM 3080ti. I have about 30-40 FPS with slowdowns.

It's an interesting game allowing for some creativity. But its numerous issues bar it from greatness. I liked playing it, but i can't say that everyone has to try it, because it makes me remember every problem and frustration i've encountered.

Awesome game, have played for over 5 years now (ignore my Steam hours) and have loved and followed the game through all of its updates, almost since release. I have to say it is a great game and was worth my money and I am looking forward for Terra Tech Worlds!

I liked :
+++ Replayability, I have done the "campaign" and all the corporations to max about 10-15 times
++ ~30 hours of gameplay to reach endgame.
++ Endgame is fun, crafting big techs or bases is what i really love to do
++ Creative AND survival are both enjoyable, either you like making techs or scavenging in survival
+ Diversity of items/blocks and their interactions 
+ Complexity of techs (vehicles you make) can be very in depth (especially with flyers)
+- Descent physics, especially flight and zero gravity vehicles, sometimes can be a little buggy however
+- Controls can be a little hard to use, but with the custom controls menu it is become less of an issue
+- Graphics aren't bad, but if you want that you'll need to wait for Terra Tech Worlds
+- Multiplayer isn't the strong point of this game as it is mostly single player, but can be played with multiple players

Actually not all that bad of a game, but the editor is strangely TERRIBLE and more of a pain to work with than it should be, especially when it's something so integral to the gameplay. The biggest editor problems are
a)Block rotation. Rotation is currently one button and toggles through all the possible rotations *in sequence*. It's as bad as it sounds. A multiple-key system to rotate on different axis' and shift the block left/right would be a godsend. 

b) Poor snap placement. The snap placement is completely unintuitive; if you try to place a cab chassis on a cab it will rarely, if ever, actually snap to the correct placement. Likewise, repeatedly placing an item in the same orientation doesn't always lead to it snapping to that orientation; you may have to rotate it each and every time. 

Lastly, the ability to aim manually would also be a significant improvement, as auto-aim does a poor job of accounting for movement and doesn't let you aim very precisely at all. I still like the game, and would give it a neutral review if I could, but there are some very cumbersome flaws in the core gameplay.

Terratech is a surprising game. Seemingly simplistic and unambitious, but the reality is that it's the exact opposite of "ocean wide and an inch deep". Terratech's maybe a few inches wide, but there's definitely at least a mile of depth here.

In terms of only an inch wide, the building mechanics are extremely intuitive and easy to grasp, just grab a block with your cursor and connect to a different block via their attachment points. Only some basic physics are simulated like mass, gravity, inertia, but it fits the game very well and allows things to remain intuitive. The campaign and NPCs are no doubt too simplified, and I wouldn't mind a more difficult and varied challenge and a reason to build and experiment, but these are secondary in this game and serve only as a unlock/progression conduit.

On the other, mile deep hand, the number of different shapes and functions of the blocks makes it so fun and engaging. From getting your first Frankenstein's monster by adding bits of your defeated foes to your own vehicle and letting it grow to a chaotic, unsightly mountain of a monstrosity. Unbalanced, moving on an ill fitting set of wheels and tracks of various sizes and purposes, bristling with random selection of weaponry, everything scavenged from the burning wrecks of your enemies. To your elegant and deadly, streamlined to perfection, pre-planned and carefully crafted, heavily armoured and armed flagship that is maybe a tank, a mining and refining complex, a flying fortress, or maybe all 3 at once. A behemoth that can obliterate any size target from beyond the horizon in a matter of seconds. And everything between these two extremes.

The building mechanics are vastly improved from the time I first played it many, many years ago. Back then, even building a simple mining, refining, selling structure was a major pain steeped in tedium and frustration. There is rarely any need to alt-tab to check wiki or forums about something specific. Building still could use many improvements though, like drag building conveyor belts, mirror building, exploded view for inspection of deep internals in large builds, modular building - now you can only place blocks one by one (patch 1.5.3 from a month ago introduced a new connecting block that allows modularity though).

Where the game falls short is the counterpart to its extremely fun building loop, the world where your creations live. There just isn't anywhere near enough challenges and reasons to build and experiment with different types of crafts and structures. The terrain, despite having fairly varied biomes, only ranges from very flat to slightly bumpy, even in the "mountains". The biomes areas are very small and scattered around in random patches. The world doesn't change as you travel, you just go, very quickly, through the same bits of grassland, desert, salt flats, hills etc. There's almost never any necessity to purpose build something to allow progression, the entire world just blends into colourful patchwork. I would love it if the biomes were much larger, both horizontally and vertically so that making a helicopter to get to the top of the mountains, or a speeder to get through the salt flats would make sense.

I've had some of the most fun during the Slippery Slope challenge, where you have to build a very specific vehicle and have restricted blocks. After an hour of failing I managed it with a tiny car utilizing a weapon with extreme recoil, mounted backwards to help me move through the obstacle course. I just wish there were more reasons to build something specific as now it boils down to making several blueprints for vehicles - regular tank, hover tank, fast tank, flying tank, and structures - defence turret, charging station, autominer template, refining and selling template. I still had plenty of fun doing those, but the game has so much unrealised potential that it leaves me wanting more.

Having said all that, not only the devs are still adding new qos features and blocks to Terratech, but they have a new game - Terratech Worlds in development, which seems to be addressing the majority, if not all of my wishlist for this game. I can't wait for that to release.

In the meantime, I'd absolutely recommend Terratech even at full price.

Forget tame sandboxes, TerraTech throws you into a vibrant alien world and screams, "Build something wild!" After 300 hours (trust me, that's just scratching the surface), I'm still concocting ridiculous mechanical monstrosities – a lumbering resource harvester with spider legs? Check. A jet fighter with spinning drill wings? Why not? The charm lies in this infinite canvas for your madcap creations, fueled by constant updates from the passionate devs. They're like mad scientists themselves, injecting the world with new biomes, crazy weapons, and endless creative possibilities.

Now, the graphics aren't going to win any beauty contests, but who needs pixel-perfect landscapes when you're busy welding together a walking fortress? My only nitpick is occasional stuttering when I unleash my inner resource baron and build monstrous processing bases. A computer upgrade mostly silenced the lag, but potato-powered rigs beware.

Ultimately, TerraTech transcends mere "game." It's an invitation to unleash your inner engineer, conquer bizarre landscapes with your own mechanical menagerie, and join a community where creativity reigns supreme. If you crave a sandbox that lets you paint with gears and bolts, fuels your tinkering addiction, and keeps things fresh with a dev team on the same crazy wavelength, this is your mechanical nirvana. Now go forth, build something glorious, and maybe share the blueprints – a fellow mad scientist might just need your masterpiece for their next interstellar rampage.

I have mixed feelings about this game. It allows for so much creativity and innovation, and is delightfully simple to understand for how complex it can be. However, the vanilla game does have one major drawback: lack of replayability. This can be solved with the addition of mods from the workshop, but even there the number of mods is finite. 

Overall, I would recommend the game, and I have high hopes for the sequel, Terra Tech Worlds. Looking forward to seeing how it improves on the current systems.

Simply put, this sandbox game is loads of fun.

In general terms, the single player campaign gives you a loose purpose: you need to face off against other techs to acquire parts and run missions to level up your faction license. This also allows you to unlock additional faction licenses which enable you to play other types of techs. Techs in general scale upwards in difficulty based upon the size and power of the tech you're currently using. You don't have to just play with the techs you've built either, you can establish elaborate industrial complexes, provide them power with various types of consumable/renewable energy, set up production queues that allow you to sort and program intelligent operations, and defend them all with automated defensive turrets. Unfortunately, these complexes don't seem to remain alive in memory if you're not in the general area, and given that you can't seem to teleport across the world from one base to the next, it really limits you to building in only one location in single player (in cooperative multiplayer, you're always tethered to the host's position). You can switch to a high speed tech to save on travel time, and then transition into a more functional tech when you arrive where you want to go, but it can also be a nuisance to recharge all your batteries if you have a particularly large tech you want to use. I didn't find the single player or multiplayer campaign restrictive, but it was definitely the various multiplayer modes are where it was most enjoyable for me. There's lots of flexibility both working collaboratively and playing competitively. Overall, the game has also progressed fairly well from it's original release, and there have been a number of quality of life improvements since I started playing.

Would recommend most of all for people who enjoy the construction and design aspect, but it's not super complicated engineering, and you can also skip that entirely by sharing tech designs with friends or downloading from the workshop if you're not particularly fond of building.

Game has not changed much over the years aside from some blocks and corporations being added. It still has all of the annoying things that plagued early versions such as: enemy techs that are just boxes of guns, enemy tech ai being horrible and just rushing at you in a straight line, enemy tech los distance being the same for all of them (allowing you to sit at the edge of their los and kill them without them fighting back).

Multiplayer still does not have crafting. Also, when you play co op, you are "tethered" to the other player and neither of you can go outside a certain range of each other. If anyone wants to go anywhere, both have to go. This is due to the engine.

Speaking of the engine, it severely limits the game. It is too far ahead for them to remake it, and I think the engine will be the downfall of this game if it isn't already. There are so many things that are impossible because of the poor engine. We will NEVER have proper multiplayer. The dream everyone had of big servers with multiple players attacking each other's bases will never ever happen.

This game could have been great, but decisions made early on have hampered it greatly. It will never be as good as it could be. It's still a little fun, but nothing much changes between each update and it seems the engine has halted progress on a lot of things that could be. I would pass on this, it's just disappointing.

This is a good game. 

However, it has two big flaws.

1 - It's super buggy. Usually, this doesn't matter, being mostly minor physics bugs, but occasionally you'll find a crash bug or worse. I've had a bug that completely broke a part of the mission progression in a campaign and I had to delete that file. 

2 - There isn't much to do. This game doesn't have much of a storyline besides connected missions, and it shows. You'll mostly find yourself doing the exact same thing over and over again, and while that thing is fun, it gets old quickly. 

If you really like the building and physics systems, you'll probably find yourself having the most fun in R&D labs building random bullshit and not with the campaign.

Terratech is an excellent open-world sandbox adventure game where players can create various block-based vehicles and embark on daring battles and explorations. With a vast library of blocks at their disposal, players can freely design and assemble their own unique vehicles, limited only by their imagination.

I've been acquainted with this game for a long time, and even after all these years, opening it up still brings out the child in me, as if I'm playing the coolest "building block" game.

Recently, I learned about the development team's new plan called "Terratech Worlds," and it's evident that the game engine has been upgraded. Now, the planets feature rivers and lakes, and I can't help but wonder what surprises await with the introduction of water-based vehicles. I remember a time when I struggled with my rudimentary English (which, to be honest, hasn't improved much), trying to express my anticipation for more complex alien environments and the need for groundbreaking vehicles to navigate them.

I'm grateful for the team's persistent updates and dedication throughout all these years.
All around good game, fun for people who like to build or tinker.

I think its about my time to write a review on this game. After almost 1000 hours across 2 steam accounts and after playing since 2016 this game means a lot to me, But I think its time I voice my opinions on the many flaws i think this game has and I would love if got fixed by the Developers.  

Now for the rant...

First, Base building is pretty much non existent. some mission content being removed(Yet I understand removing the base building "tutorial" missions as pretty much all base building components being removed, but still.) , especially some of my favorite missions, and just a lot of other things removed which is a big killer for this game for me and my friends, and now I understand the world borders, but C'mon make it an option or something as it is an absolute pain having to either wait for your friends to catch up to you or being limited when flying to a little circle around your group. And IMO the MOST annoying of all of these "flaws" is that you all have to stick togethor and cant all go do different missions which makes everything take longer and makes the game a lot less fun when playing with a big group.

With all that said, If you don't plan to play with friends I highly recommend it besides the occasional bugs its a great experience can do just about anything you want, But multiplayer/co-op is just so limiting it take most of the fun of the game out. Yes, it works. Does it work well? IMO No. ( I personally do not see myself playing this game with friends anytime in the future until these things are fixed. )

If you don't feel like reading, to sum it all up if you want to play with friends do NOT get the game, But if you plan to play solo I recommend it overall, I give Terratech a 9/10 in solo, but a 6/10 in multiplayer.

Horrible autosave, literally autosaved mid combat! Only 1 autosave, seems to autosave mere seconds to a minute. Lost an item by accidentally dragging it into a trade center, which is extremely easy to do since you probably want to build near a trade center. Extremely annoying AI always tries to get behind you. Weapons do not aim where the enemy is going but rather where the enemy is, making you miss every shot while the enemy is moving. Thimble collector resources (tractor beam) gets stuck in your craft. Something doesn't feel right about the environment, feels like it's missing variety. Some things are not explained at all. Most items will be left on the ground and cannot be sold. Enemies may roam around and attack these objects (or the seat block). Some of these things you can not get back until you progress a quest state that unlocks them, causing momentary annoyance. You will get new shipments and parts in the wild, these seemingly have to be applied to your current craft or attached to the new seat and taken control of in order to get them to the base. What you want to do is put those parts into a storage or teleport it where they need to be, or get the shipment sent to a specific location, all from the very start. Items snap weirdly and aren't smartly rotated by default. Apparently the game may also crash instead of shutting down when you tell it too. 

And THIS is what a very positive rating game looks like! It's a huge disappointment and a trap! Do not let the rating be the only thing that convinces you to buy the game, even on a discount, some things are just far too frustrating to deal with. I may just be petty, but this is not a good beginner experience by any means and beginner experience is extremely important.

I'm gonna be real - this is a weird case for me. TerraTech is a game I adore. TerraTech is a game I despise. Both of these exist in equal measure and I can't decide between them half the time. Let's run down what leaves me feeling this way:

+ The building system is phenomenal. Making techs, making turrets, and making terrifyingly complex money-laundering factories is all really fun. It's quick, simple, and evokes a sense of playing with something like LEGO.
- There is no 'safe mode' for building. When building, you MUST consider the time of day and the presence of any enemies nearby. You may not pause. You must always think about how long it will take. As well, all buildings you make are destructible - even the harmless, inactive ones.

+ The snowballing of your tech's power can be absolutely addictive. When you make your tech stronger bit by bit until anyone who even remotely looks at you wrong gets eviscerated, it's satisfying as hell.
- The same effect can and will apply to you. Powerful techs can be dropped in at a moment's notice and crush you into dust if you're unlucky. The autosave system is also incredibly bad at *not* saving seconds before and/or after disaster.

+ Making your perfect, automated manufacturing plant that handles every resource perfectly is sometimes more fun than games based entirely around that mechanic, whereas here it's merely a side project.
- The grind to get resources for money, as well as the fact it leaves you and your constructs open to danger, can be utterly agonizing.

So, that should help explain things. You may notice a theme - I'm quite fond of most mechanics, but the combat and grinding can really drag the experience down. This game is a weird case where I love just as much as I hate. So, why am I recommending it? Simple; If you are willing to accept these flaws, this game pulls off most of its mechanics better than ANY alternative on the market. As well, updates are constant and mod support is pretty good. If you can bite the bullet on the worse parts of the game, there's so much charm and care put into every corner of the game.

... Except how you can change enemy strength in the sandbox mode but not in the campaign. I'm begging for this to become an accessibility feature someday.

This game is a lot of fun to play, and the devs are always working on improving the game for both the stable and unstable branches. You can make your own vehicles/bases/whatever or borrow someone elses, so long as you're having fun. Just be warned that as of the time of this review, the game can get very laggy, although the devs have definitely improved that and will surely continue to do so.

Edit 5 years on: TerraTech has gotten a lot better in many many ways, lag very much among them. New corporations, biomes, missions, blocks, paints, tons of quality of life improvements, this game is great and very much worth your time and money!

I haven't seen many vehicle building games floating around. Combining it with a survival/automation game makes Terratech a unique case. I recommend it for that and the space wld-west vibes it has going.

You can build and drive any vehicle you want. So long as you got the money and/or ressources to craft them. To get access to better blocks from the different corporations you'll have to complete quest for them, be it destroying some rogue/rival prospectors in a certain area, by collecting and selling the specified ressources or doing certain challenges.

Driving in this game is good. At least, until you get to rougher terrain, then it becomes strangely slippery but you car never flips. Even if you're hovering above the ground, you're gonna feel every bump on the way up a mountain. It makes driving through anything that is slighlty mountaineous a chore. It's even worse when you fall into a big hole and the only way out is by using the slow moving tractor beam.

The world you'll be travelling in is... Basic. It's procedurally generated and is overall flat. Biomes do have a distinct identity and specific resources appearing on them, but they blend into one another easily aside from like, 3.
Most of the resources (trees, ore outcrops and oil wells) are bunched together. But they don't respawn, at least as I can tell, so you'll have to explore. In fact to take quests and sell resources, you'll often need to find a GSO outpost.

Ok now fighting. Its pretty intense, as long as the AI isn't driving itself in a ditch. You won't ever find an actual player in the game, but you'll definitely see player made creations. You can easily tell it was made by a player if it is covered in weapons. But in general, you'll mostly see generic vehicules from every faction. They're all agressive, unless you have far more DPS than them, they'll just run away without even shooting.
Speaking of the weapons, there's a large variety of them. From small short range laser to massive naval battleships. The great majority of them aim automatically towards enemy cores, but you're the one that tells them WHEN to shoot. This gives the game some strategy, though I found that covering yourself in GeoCopr armor, having Hawkeye shields and weapons usually allows you to facetank everything.

During your time exploring and fighting, you'll have some really good music. Be it ambient or a fighting music, it alwasy keeps a wild-west vibe. Seriously, that's the best part of exploring. You feel like you are an old prospector on a gold rush, but this time in space. There's even a banjo and/or accoustic guitar in almost every song, its great.

I can't think of a way to finish this review outside of just "buy it plz it be good space wild-west"

Prefacing here, this is from someone who managed to make this their 'forever game' for a long while.. and is more so mixed than undeniably positive. I'm not here to discourage someone from trying it out though.

The game's good, core mechanics work solidly, there's a surprising amount of different things to utilize, the artstyle's unique and simplistic enough that i managed to mod it to a limited degree despite having zero prior skills (which by the way, modding scene's quite a thing, albeit it works best with a sideloader/companion application), the skill floor and ceiling is.. janky. It's not really that difficult, mostly in the early game and a select few instances beyond it, however losing your battlecruiser on wheels can be *really* costly if it is actually outmatched overall, especially if you've managed to increase the difficulty with something like working plane ai. Kind of encourages either cheesing encounters if possible or abusing saves. Or you could make something nimble and relatively replaceable. The high end of skill is mostly in airships (either antigrav or the beneficial hoverbug) and/or trying to make something meta and/or look good, the highest end is *very* blatant when you see it.

Game's selling point is seemingly that simplicity, it's simply not built to carry a more hardcore community (i would not consider myself one of those sorts, despite the hours) unlike some other games, particularly From The Depths where's it's the polar opposite. Does make it pretty accessible to younger kids though, which *is* what the game's target audience is.

On more negative ends, the game is partially botched on a fundamental level, quite a few bugs (like crafting which is riddled with them) alongside other things like being a single core game and still poorly optimized enough that the console versions are significantly more strict on what you can have down at any time, particularly the switch. It's also fundamentally a singleplayer game, what is working in multiplayer is nothing short of a miracle, especially crafting, because it's been pretty much stapled onto the game.
There's also the community. Since this is a game aimed towards kids that wouldn't be allowed on discord due to age it's quite the mess. Not inherently bad, but you're going to see and get quite the range of things, not to mention the bad apples you get with a community full of young kids.

Generally speaking, the game's good but not exceptional, the community's.. weird. Probably something neat to check out if you're having a stroke over complexity in other building games. Or if you find it comical to mod in the chance of a 5 pack turret squad to mow down your early-midgame tech out of nowhere. I speak from experience.

I'm not sure if I played enough to give a full review but as of now I've played 38hours and noticed some pretty glaring problems.
Overall, the game is great, especially for people who enjoys crafting and battle and therefore I will still recommend it.
The cons however, might make this unsuited for everyone to buy.

First off, there are certain quality-of-life functions that the game does not provide and thus makes things unnecessarily more difficult:
1. Every change you make to your vehicle / base is permanent
2. There is an undo button but it only appears IF you remove a connecting piece and everything falls apart
3. Because small changes are permanent, you will find pieces you accidentally moved turn into a treasure hunt (trying to find where you accidentally stick that piece to)
4. Additionally, items fly when you move them sometimes EVEN THOUGH you did not let go of the left mouse button (that means that get flung away altho you didn't do that), because if the mouse move out of the screen, you click and hold is cancelled and without a good undo option, its gone (sometimes the piece will fly to under another building where you'll find your missing piece much later, sometimes it just disappear under other blocks and you need to remove the outer parts to discover it hidden within)
5. Your base can topple for no reason. I had a 4 foundation fence with guns. i see 1 foundation destroyed and the whole building is overturned on the ground. I did not remove any anchors and there are 3 foundations left. 1/2 the pieces are broken on the floor and I had to send the rest of the items to my inventory.

Second, I feel the content is rather limited, the main gameplay in singleplayer sticks to questing and leveling. Resource hunts are not fun. Getting money / credit is a grind. There are cool vehicles that appears here and there to attack you, why can't there be vehicles that appear when guarding resources? Or if there is, i have yet to encounter any so far.

Third, flight seems difficult. I am at the point in game where I am getting hover parts and propellers + plane engines. I've tried several builds but there are no way to make this smooth enough for combat. Maybe because i shoot and fly too fast to do enough damage and spend most of my time trying to adjust. Also the bump damage hurts my vehicle too much so far. Lastly, I feel that the planes cannot recharge batteries for shields and repair modules as easily as a land vehicle and the vehicle furnace I need is not unlocked so far for mobile recharge - besides i doubt this will be easy either because i cannot farm wood / fuel easily from the air. I will try to resolve the above using 100% hovercraft parts, maybe this will elevate things but doesn't remove how forward propellers, wings, and rotary blades doesn't feel fluid.

Fourth, there are many bugs unsolved in this game imo, like things that gotten harvest AI deleted. Its been 5 years since the game release and its still unsolved.

Well me and my friends logged in for the first time yesterday and got sucked in. What seemed at first like a very simple lego style car building game, quickly became a survival, crafting, and factory game. We started making multiple specialized vehicles that you can hop between for different tasks. I won't spoil anything else but the depth and possibility of the game revealed itself to us as we played for 8 hours straight. I usually wait longer to recommend games but I can already tell that this game is a gem.

Game is fun until you start encountering game-breaking bugs and other annoyances. Story missions might not load after accepting them; there is a marker on the map, but nothing spawns when you get there. There is no fix for this bug, which also appears to be a couple of years old. You have to start a new game or load a save before the bug occurred. This happened to me twice with different missions, causing me to lose a lot of the progress.

In co-op mode, you can spawn whatever tech you want from your saved ones, duplicating the parts and ruining the progression.

Placing parts is uncomfortable; sometimes, you have to rotate a part a dozen times before it's where you want it to be. There are no separate X, Y, and Z placing controls, like in kerbal space program, for example.

Wheel steering cannot be turned off. 

List goes on...

It's disappointing.

[u]Update, 12/09/2023 (Positive)[/u]:
Finally, developers have reached the point where they made weapon grouping possible through use of logic blocks. Look for Reticule Research Keybinder block, and once you find it, you will have whole 10 groups for weapon/equipment grouping. Enjoy!

[u]Update, 16/02/2023 (Negative)[/u]:
Years have passed, developer continuously sent email ads to buy skin packs, whilst not implementing a crucial QoL feature, custom keyboard shortcuts for modules/module groups, despite answering almost 4 years ago that they're working on it. Impossible work it seems.

[u]Original, 22/02/2019 (Negative)[/u]:
Will change to positive once per-module customizable hotkeys will be implemented.

@Doc Robotnik, controls are ok for small vehicles. But absolutely unopperable for huge mobile factories equipped with multitude of modules and weapons. And the game is exactly aimed at having such monstrous vehicles in command.

So yeah, after 40 hours of gameplay, when you ride massive monstrous factory full of guns, missiles and anything you can imagine it is absolutely frustrating that you can only fire everything at once without having ability to define even simplest weapon group shortcuts. This is also why it is only 40 hours, and not 400.

There was even [url=https://forum.terratechgame.com/index.php?threads/0-7-4-nuterra-v0-4-2-worldeditor.9049/]unofficial mod[/url] that added per-module type hotkeys. If you can't do it, while modmaker can - what kind of developers are you?

IDK... the concept is cool, but the core game revolves around resource management that is hamstrung and the rest of the game is combat with enemies that seem to lack variety by the time you get good parts to use.

You need to gather resources for one, this is largely an annoyance at the larger scale with no option to automate half the resources because for some reason, while I cant think of a single game similar mechanics are an issue, the dev here couldnt get AI resource harvesters working, which honestly sounds ridiculous to the point Im not sure I believe it.

The other even bigger issue is the conveyor systems. They dont operate intuitively, or based on visual markings, you cant control the direction of them if they are 1 tile long, you need to have isolated loops for the resource calls from manufacturing buildings to work, but then theres no way to do all that while accounting for overflow.

The rest of the game is kind of basic, filled with the same enemies over and over, even though theres meant to be a system that uses player saved designs to invade other players, I still see the same designs in the rare invasions, and it obviously must not apply to the normal enemy spawns because I definitely keep seeing only a small handful of enemies repeatedly, with a noticeable lack of enemies designed from the higher tier parts I've unlocked and use on my own vehicles.

The game definitely needs the following:
1. Resource automation in the form of either mobile harvesters or expanding mining nodes for all resources.
2. A simpler conveyor system, full connections between loops, or a kind of filter block to pull orphaned resources not travelling to storage or to be used.

Whether you're creative or not, there will be something for you to do in this game. Competitive? Try Sumo, Racing or the Deathmatch mode. Like combat more than anything? Multiplayer and Campaign have a lot of that. Like a story with a game? Once again, the Campaign is for you. And if you're the creative type, oh man are you going to love this game. If you can think of it, you can make it with a little time. If you want to share your creations, this game even has a Steam Workshop! It even has a few mods in there for additional content if you're not quite satisfied. The game even pulls a GMod and lets you use your mods in peer to peer servers that automatically download the mods for you upon joining! I cannot recommend a game more than this one. Its a shame its not more popular since this is a game a lot of people would enjoy. So don't torture yourself with Overwatch or League of Legends, play TerraTech!

Played: March 2023

I actually completed this game twice in a row only taking a break of about one week.  Since it is relatively short, I felt like playing it again to see how much quicker I could complete it (less than half the time).  With no discernable ending to the game, I chose the "End" to be when I maxed out full XP in each of the corporations: GSO, GeoCorp, Venture, Hawkeye, Better Future and Reticule Research.

After first testing the game a few years ago and not liking how quickly your starting GSO vehicle gets damaged having to rebuild it, I stopped playing.  I didn't want to have to deal with that constantly.  I should have given it a further test as once you get into the GeoCorp parts your durability greatly increases, even though your weapons still stink.  So how did I get better weapons?  I watched a Let's Play video by someone and saw them defeat the bridge guard that stands alone on a small short bridge.  The only bridge like that in the game.  If you can defeat that enemy you can get a number of Hawkeye weapons very early in the game.  It's not easy, and requires you to stay to his side and not let him hit you with his powerful weapons as you pick him apart.  Save before trying this method.

There's some debate online as to which corporation has the best weapons.  My favorites ended up being anything Homing, like the homing missiles that both Venture (Venture Avalanche Launcher) and Hawkeye (Hawkeye Cruise Missile) have.  GSO (GSO Missile Battery) also has homing missiles but you have to get lucky finding them on an enemy you destroy since you can't purchase them until your GSO XP enters the final Level 5 stage.  And if you do find any of these, don't let them get destroyed otherwise you won't be able to redeploy that vehicle if parts are missing and you don't have unused replacements in your inventory!!!

Other than weapons, my favorite vehicle body parts remained GeoCorp's big yellow blocks.  There are so many to find from defeated enemies and the largest (GeoCorp Behemoth Wheels) worked best for me in climbing over the steep landscape.  My big vehicle was slow though with a top speed on the salt flats of about 46 mph.  I later replaced the two rear tires with the largest (Venture Titan Wheels) which increased my speed to 66 mph.  I kept the front two tires Behemoths since they stuck further out and helped climbing the steep hills.

Another important thing to do is construct a vehicle with a pivoting anchor in the center bottom of your truck.  This allows for you to anchor your vehicle and still pivot your vehicle all while deploying a rear attached SCU.  Remember those three letters "SCU".  Hopefully you can get a SCU early on in the game as they let you gather destroyed vehicle parts so much faster.  If you get one or two, think about attaching one to the rear of your vehicle so you can deploy the anchor and gather parts quickly.  Finding relatively flat ground to anchor on can be tricky though.  Near the end of the game, the (Better Future Sky Anchor) on a ground vehicle is a dream come true.  Nearly any ground formation can be anchored on and it even lets you move and drive your vehicle a short distance to position yourself for loot and fighting all while sucking up parts in the SCU.

Eventually, you're going to need to use different smaller vehicles to complete the mission challenges for speed tracks, hover obstacle courses and flying planes.  The default vehicles the game gives you are usually good enough, but some required tweaking to make them better.

And lastly Invaders... when an invader warning appears I recommend positioning yourself to kill them to get some good parts.  And keep doing these.  However, eventually you may get sick of them showing up, and you can get them to stop showing up.  Simply let one land as you drive away and that will be last one you ever encounter.  It will stay on the map for you to kill later, if you want, which will resume the periodic Invaders showing up from time to time.

I've owned this game for a very long time now and been watching others play for even longer. I liked this game a lot, and there are many things that this game does right, from the variety of blocks to play with to the rich personality of each of the corporations' NPC guides.

Sadly though, it has barely changed over the last few years. While it may look like TerraTech receives frequent patches and lots of attention from its caring developers (which is true), most of the changes consist of the addition of a few easy missions, some new blocks to bring parity between corporations*, and the usual bug fixes. However, none of these of a notable effect on how you will play the game differently. On top of that, the game's age is very apparent in the performance. Even on a mid-range system, the FPS tanks whenever you get a single large or several medium sized crafts loaded. 

* Personally, I dislike how each corporation essentially has the same blocks and functions as each other. Apart from weight and block health differences, this removes the need to choose between corporations when outfitting your craft. If every corporation has the same offerings, it severely restricts the depth of building and makes the differences in each corporation minute.


I remember being excited looking at the original roadmap for this game posted many years ago. It's pretty unfortunate that almost all of the features have been scrapped or otherwise not implemented yet. Having said all this, it's still not a bad game; there's plenty to do and enjoy, and even more can be found in the mods people develop. Just don't expect anymore than what's already in the game.
Here's hoping that TerraTech Worlds can succeed where this game failed.

Very fun, glad they've done all of their recent QOL updates. Still has some areas that could use improvement, but overall has a BUNCH of content (almost as many blocks as what freaking MINECRAFT has) and a lot of fun to have before the game gets boring.

The game has a definite low-res art style, but if you crank the graphics settings the game really starts looking good. However, you'll need a good computer for this as it's a sandbox game made in unity (which makes it really hard to optimize from a developer standpoint), so make sure you have an intel 12th gen or ryzen 5000 cpu or above [good single-core performance, core counts won't matter for this game lol], and a rtx 3080 / radeon 6800XT or above.

Overall, TerraTech has really come a long way. The devs are starting to really listen to their community and add features to the game that are genuinely fun/cool/helpful. It's definitely worth the money.

Terra Tech is an outstanding game that I have spent many, many hours playing. Whether you want to play a Lego styled sandbox game, exiting adventure and discovery game, or to create a prospector empire, Terra Tech has it all. With tons of blocks, loads of missions and an infinite world, it's hard to find yourself bored with this game. As there is multiple ways to get blocks in this game, there is many different play styles : crafting, adventuring, annihilating; the choice is yours. There may be the occasional bug or issue but they are not at all very common. The fact that this game is getting many updates past early access is awesome. The DLC is well worth it, and the game itself is a good price. With the new addition of a much better multiplayer mode then before, Terra Tech is now a blast with friends too. I definitely recommend this game, and I think that the many pros out way the small amount of cons.

TL;DR: Great sandbox adventure game where your imagination is the limit and can be enjoyed with multiple different play styles and even with your friends.

Ever since Robocraft went downhill TerraTech has been filling the void in my heart the Robocraft left. While it certainly doesn't completely fill that void it comes very close. I have been playing this game since 2017 and I happily call myself a veteran. I recently returned to TerraTech after a long break due to life and the fact that I was playing other games. When I came back, though, I was not expecting all the new and fantastic content I saw. When I stoped playing Hawkeye had only just come out and now there's better future base building and much more. I honestly cannot express in words how good this game is. If you were a fan of Robocraft you'd certainly feel at home. However, don't go in thinking that this is Robocraft under a new name because it really isn't nearly as comparable to Robocraft as you'd think. I started playing this game because it was similar to Robocraft, however it has, grown out of Robocrafts shadow and has established itself in not just my heart but thousands of dedicated fans and truly allows you to express yourself while destroying enemies. My only wishes for this game are that we get more blocks to use to make different shapes. I'd also like to see things like spider legs. I feel spider legs would fit into the game well. Maybe they could also have the ability of letting climb up steeper terrain than normal.

TerraTech is a very good and enjoyable game imo with many BIG pros and little cons, while also maintaining quite the community of creators and active devs, constantly creating amazing things, adding interesting functional (and meme) parts, as well as the absolutely insane builds you would expect from the internet, being mainly based on getting blocks from enemies, quests and buying them, to build and destroy things
Pros:
- Very active community and developer work
- Quite polished and very good looking
- Very large amount of options to create (and destroy) things creatively and simply, from rather straight forward mass destruction machines, to mining operations to get money and manufacture parts
- Quite enjoyable (although somewhat steep) learning path
- Several types of different quests like combat, search over an area, races and obstacle courses, resource extraction assignments 
- *gun walls*
- Several different types of weaponry, including cannons, light repeater guns, lasers, railguns, missiles, mortars, melee weapons and also bombs
- Varied biomes containing different types of materials to sell and to manufacture
- Several faction focused blocks with both general and specialized use, such as lighter blocks, heavily armored blocks, faster and small wheels, BIG wheels, wings for fliers, chopper blades, gyroscopes, and so on
- much more

cons: 
- Can get somewhat buggy due to physics and flying blocks from resources and blowing up enemies
- Possibly confusing when you start making gigantic machines, making building them a pain
- Somewhat annoying shield and regen bubble functionalities, being that they have fixed sizes and are constantly active, meaning that your batteries are constantly draining, and somewhat hard to position when it comes to big machines
- Learning curve can be steep
- Anchors sometimes refuse to... well... anchor, especially when you have a big build and uneven terrain
- Somewhat convoluted manufacturing mechanics (personal opinion, and dont even know how it could be different, it just feels off)
- Terrain can be very difficult to pass by, with very intense and sudden elevations making it hard to pass through without fliers or very strong boosters

In general, its a very worthwhile and fun game, and would reccomend every sandbox builder lover to try it out, if the chance is given ofc
...And dont forget your black hole when you place it to gather loot, its annoying to drive all the way back when its far

The longer I play games, the more I appreciate experiences I create for myself. With more powerful hardware capable of running massive worlds in real time, I'm always surprised at how restrictive the larger games feel. We tend to think of player choice in terms of two dialogue options that functionally make very little difference to the outcomes. Not the case here with TerraTech!

Here you get a real taste of freedom and choice in a game. with the exception of some of the missions that are meant to guide you through learning new blocks, you can approach the whole world however you like with your computer legos (uncapitalized as I feel it deserves to be a regular noun by now). Want to build a behemoth and roll over any obstacle in your way? Go for it. Want to slam every thruster available onto every surface and test the game's maximum speed? No one's stopping you. Want to strap on enough ordinance to end an entire nation in a single volley? No war crime laws here. Want to build a super efficient factory line and mining operation? You already know!

If there's any downside, it's that I also play other very open games and I have to compare TerraTech to them. In Subnautica, there's an overarching goal that drives a lot of your decision making in terms of resource use and designs. Here resources are infinite and goals are very short term. It's a bit too much sandbox, and not enough jungle gym (structured climbing). It was interesting in Subnautica that knowing you'd leave everything behind, somehow you became more attached to it. Also in TerraTech, on top of infinite resources, you can bag of holding store all your blocks and blueprints; so it's hard to value anything you've gained.

However, as an introduction to more true freedom building games, TerraTech is practically perfect. It's definitely a game I'd buy to keep in my collection to pass on to my kids some day. So what kind of drink would I compare it to? I'd say it's more like a starter brewing kit. Just enough of the basics to get you interested, and enough tools to expand your ways of thinking about something you already like.

Great game it has so many parts that the limits of each build are limitless the crafting system is okay and easy to do and the Main Story has been a lot of fun and allows the game to teach you how to play and all the parts and classes of parts. Multiplayer I have not played a lot but playing it shows you just how amazing the building in the game can be with each car you can see that the building is only limited by you and how many pieces you have. Now Cons, well you cannot mass select your parts, so when you build you have to do 1 at a time, and if you want to move a section of your car up or down you have to do it 1 at a time which takes more time. There is also no way to lock parts to a car so if you grab a piece that holds a lot of others they all will fall off and you will have to rebuild. but you can save whole car builds so that is a big help. The next con is there is no auto-save so make sure to save or you can lose hours of work building and playing. There has also been some artifacting around the stores where you buy car parts and a couple of bugs that are not huge just visual bugs. The game was pretty fucking intense in my first 17 hours. I was only concerned with fighting other enemy techs, upgrading mine and enjoying the game's manufacturing part. The gameplay cycle of battling and evolving was great, with the addition of missions (which looked great, but got annoying fast). It had me hooked so bad that I couldn't stop playing the game to sleep. There's a lot of content to explore and the ability to create your own tech, but I found the game extremely easy. Every enemy was dead in one shot, but at the same time, I didn't like seeing my tech being destroyed, so I can't think of a way to balance it. In the late game, there wasn't much to do, so I started exploring the community content. There were some reskins and a lot of community buildings, so I started testing some and found out that airplanes are such a cool thing to control in this game. It made me spend another hour in the game before finally closing it. It's a great game to spend a few hours on, but I don't feel like I'm going to play it anytime soon

TerraTech's a weird game to recommend, but I do. 

The core game loop is engaging, and it has a lot of creative potential if you're into that. The central mechanics are tactile and fun in a way that keeps you engaged for a good long while. The building is stellar, and even just driving and flying around can be fun. The combat is overly simplistic, however. 

If TerraTech is guilty of anything it's wasted potential. Its mechanics and systems are building up to a pinnacle that's not there. Its world is uniform and sterile, and there's nothing like long-term goals. 

The base building that turns out to almost never be necessary,  the simplistic combat, and a number of other features suggest that TerraTech really, really wishes it was a hybrid RTS. It just feels like its ultimate design goal is something it currently isn't, and likely never will be, and that's a shame.

Still, has a fair bit going for it. Definitely a solid few evenings fun if you're into vehicle builders, and the combat/salvage/combat loop is rock solid here. 

Call it a 6/10. Solid, passable product. Not stellar, but definitely good.
