I would love to recommend this game, but the absolute frustration with the poorly written missions later in the game that take all your progress and basically tell you to stick it where the sun doesn't shine... yeah, that's beyond frustrating.

Build 30 techs that do different things:  Check
Create self-feeding bases that can make you money while you AFK:  Check
Work on your "aeroplanes", jets, tanks, massive war machines, etc.  But, can you use them?  No.  

Here's a specific build you need for this specific mission that you have to pay BB coins for.  Seriously?  What if I want to use my own?  SOmetimes you can, but usually just for the racing stuff.   If you want to make a build that can climb icy mountain?  Forget it.  "Looks like you missed a checkpoint"  or "looks like you slid right out of bounds" when you're direcly on the path.  Have a tall mech you're using for Hubbl missions?  Sorry, that's not allowed.  Too close to the upper bounds....  Want to use your super hovercraft that you built to be VERY stable and easy to fly?  No, sorry.. it has to fit through these small hoops.  Want to make anti-grav easier (it's a joke and the developers know it) by making your own stable build a million and a half ways you've engineered it to work well?  No, sorry... it has to be able to go through these small hoops and only in this way.... Want to use your super duty tech that goes over 200KPH for racing?  Nope, has to be a specific size and you can't touch the sides of the road or you get disqualified.  Want to use your painstakingly created jet for missions?  Only if it has specific weapons and they can't be lock-on or anything.

I mean, for a game that touts its creativity and sandbox-like approach to building, it's very restrictive when it comes to missions you literally HAVE to get through in order to get to the later game material.  Things like icy mountain, time trials, hovercraft flying, Anti-grav timed racing, etc... are beyond annoying and usually bugged to one degree or another. 

I did icy mountain on a small tech I built specifically for it.  Nope.  Glitched every single time and that's a mission you DO NOT want to do more than once.  Tried it with 3 different techs and different VERSIONS of the same tech...  "looks like you missed a checkpoint".  No, no I really didn't.  Sadly this game is still buggy after how many years?

This is a great game if you just want to mess around in the sandbox mode, but doing the missions and trying to progress is a joke.  Don't bother.  Also, if you want to make really big, involved self-automated bases that mine, refine, sell, etc...  be prepared to climb into the UFC ring with the camera.  It's... beyond frustrating since you can't actually CENTER the camera over your base.  You have to work with zooming in and out from your tech.  Which.. is a mind-blowing failure in terms of a game that centers around BUILDING THINGS.

It's a sad day when you can spend almost 100 hours in a game and then realize it was for nothing when you get to the later missions and see that nothing you created can be used.  Normally I would look at someone wiht 70+ hours in a game that leaves a negative review and think "they're salty about something and they obviously love the game", but not in this case.  In this case I had fun right up until I tried to "play the game".

Up to now I've only played the campaign. It has a decent progression, gathering blocks and upgrading your vehicles. What's a pretty decent idea is sadly hindered by a lot of issues.

The first and most glaring one is actually building your vehicles. For a game centred on the building aspect, it's unforgivable how poor the interface for building actually is. While the camera is decent, I find myself constantly fighting with actually placing blocks in the correct positions, and more importantly, rotating a block to the correct position. Blocks become pretty varied eventually, with many attachment points, and the only way to change orientation is by cycling 'backward' or 'forward' through what the game considers acceptable options, and this list often does not contain the option you actually need (despite it being a valid option) and you only find this out after having arbitrarily rotated the damn piece 150 times. 


Then there's actually getting the blocks. Sadly, many blocks seem to barely show up in shops or enemy drops, leading you to need to harvest resources and craft blocks if you want particular ones. Which is where the second issue starts. 

Harvesting is decent enough but crafting is incredibly awkwardly designed and above that, it's a buggy mess, which often causes endless loops of resources that don't get taken in by refineries, fabricators that stop producing their block on repeat despite abundance of resources, or just jobs for components not getting scheduled at all.

Also, you can forget about making mining outposts since rendering stops for anything further than 500 m away from the player, so miners  that you leave in a location basically do nothing unless you actually stay very close to it, completely defeating their point. 

Finally, the player is given basically no information on anything. All blocks only get a generic description (often gratingly tongue-in-cheek) and nothing else. No weight, no health, no attack strength for weapons, no capacity for batteries, nothing. You can only find this stuff out through trial and error.

I want to like it, the idea is good, and I did have some fun with it, but the execution gets frustrating pretty soon.

[h1] TLDR: [/h1] As you can see I have 50+ hours in, and I had a blast. It's a good game to just mindlessly grind. While it's not perfect it is simple and enjoyable compared to the other games in the market right now. It's good and it's cheap with only the R&D labs i deem as necessary DLC the rest are for skins. and R&D labs is essentially a sandbox that you don't really need. It's cheap so buy it, if it's too expensive then get in on sale.

[h1] CONS: [/h1]

- Parts rotation is dumb: just right right-click it and hope it will be in the position you want. You can place additional blocks around it to "block" the other positions, but yeah it's just infuriating have a system were you can select which axis to turn it.

- Story/parts progression: In order to progress you need to do missions, these are provided by those station things (that I forgot the name of) well all in all it's fine, but if you spam missions on one of those stations at a certain point no new story missions will appear and you need to go to a far away station to progress. it's just annoying, hop in your speedy jet and find a far away station to be your next base.

- Poor optimization: I'm lagging from a game that looks less than roblox (lol) but really I'm on a 720p windowed on Fast setting and I'm still getting FPS drops. I can run GTA V on high 1080p @60fps so idk.

- Can't replay finished missions: Good because you can progress, Bad because you can't do them again. Missions that add extra stuff in maps like half-pipes and ramps will disappear. Sucks because some of them are cool and fun, but you can't do them again unless you restart a new game.

- HE is too powerful nerfing them neuters their power: The Cruise "DOOM" Missile will absolutely destroy everything from other techs to your own techs. Due to how HE works it can destroy blocks deep within your tech even if you spam other blocks in front of them. But nerfing them (with a mod Nerf explosions i think) absolutely makes them useless it prolongs the battle, which is actually fun but it can be annoying as it takes too long. There's no in between, I still use the mod btw.

-Varying factions with different aesthetics: Hawkeye is full black, GSO looks generic, Geocorp is all yellow. It is fine if you'll make a tech from one faction only. But some parts are so useful that it's difficult to do so. Hence you'll have a black armor with yellow tracks and white guns, not good to look at. There are skins but it is rather limited. Thankfully there are mods for skins.

[h1] PROS: [/h1]

- Simple creation: Drag and drop, while parts are limited with their connection surfaces, there are a lot of them with specific purpose in varying factions. Making a helicopter is usually hard in most games like this, but here it is easier. Still complex and needs to balance it properly but with that one Better Future part that can hold it in place makes it easier to fly. I am a human with a monkey brain I approve.

- Virtually endless map: If you want to make a base but not found the perfect place for it you can just keep going and find that perfect valley for you.

- Bigger is not better: while being big brings a lot of things in the table, a small tech can just hide beneath you and destroy you if given enough time, and you'll lose all that time and creds you spent on it. YOU can do this to bigger techs as well. Shield stops most bullets/shells and missile explode on impact, but HE can penetrate it and do damage AOE style. And energy drops fast if you don't pay attention to it.

- Fun mindless grind: Create a giant tech with one purpose, to split the world in half. While there's no terraforming you can clear forest worth of trees to reap world ending profits. You can alaso make a portable refinery so you can just go around and destroy trees and send it to orbit while moving. It lags a lot though :(.

-Mod support: Base game too limited for you? or is it too boring? don't worry you can spice it up with mods you can even add water.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
A great game to mindlessly grind, there are missions and in the beginning parts and creds are limited. But given enough time and effort you can be a multi millionaire spend all of it in one tech. Only to all of it be destroyed because you run out of energy for your shields lol. You can be creative and make a mobile bunker with a fully working refinery, make a land battleship, or a floating fortress. Heck I've spent 2 hours making a quintuple copter that looks like a drop ship, fully armored of course with guns and missiles out the ass. AND the best thing it functions like an actual heli thankful to that one better future tech. Buy it I highly recommend, get it on sale if you want the other DLCs. Oh and the game is fully released AND their still updating it in the beta, absolutely chads compared to the other indie games studios.

P.S. I think there was an update and so the game broke lol. My mods are not updated I think and I should wait before opening this game again. Cheers to those mod creators.

After over 500 hours in this game, I can thoroughly not recommend it with full confidence. I've been quite active in the community for a very long time, and I think I have a solid understanding of the fundamental issues with this game and more it's development.

The game is just broke as shit. They push it as a co-op game but multiplayer is almost entirely a broken and buggy mess and also locks off almost everything that makes the game fun (mining, crafting, scrapping, any sort of manufacturing past literally just selling resource chunks). When multiplayer released, everyone kinda just assumed that it was gonna be one of those things that would be added further down the line, but clearly its just shelved, and multiplayer is gonna be a boring and empty husk. Considering literally every other vehicle building game has a great multiplayer system that is so much fun, there really is no reason to buy this game as it brings nothing to the table inherently. Its also awfully optimized and runs like shit when you have even a slightly large vehicle, mostly due to how the game is so spagetticoded.

The building system is also cancerous. Rotating blocks is done by pressing a SINGLE button over and over again until you get the right orientation which can take upwards of 30 seconds on blocks that have lots of different possible orientations, there is NO MIRROR MODE!!!!!!!!! which I do not even understand why it is still this way and considered acceptable, and in general all the systems are far too simple and lack depth and intrigue compared to other games.

Finally, this game is just a damn ghost town. I doubt many people will even read this because this game has so little traffic these days. Devs can't even bother to do actual content updates and instead push shitty paid DLC skin packs trying to hemorrhage off the community's goodwill. We haven't got an actual substantial content update in years that was not "two new blocks and a mission that takes 15 minutes to beat".

In conclusion, this game brings nearly nothing of depth to the vehicle building genre as a whole. It's a great game to get you started in the genre, but games like FTD are far more in-depth and fun in multiplayer, and games like Cosmoteer do the "Intuitive building system that is actually quite in depth" shtick far better. 

(Also, I really didn't want to mention this, but the TT devs are funded by a Chinese mega-corporation, and around the time they received investment they retconned much of the dialogue to involve "subtle" anti capitalist wisecracks. I really don't care, but seriously?)

Updated 3/31/2023

The Gist: 

So as an early access person, I enjoyed the game, I enjoyed it thoroughly.  The single player campaign is repetitive, somewhat boring. Multiplayer is always what makes or breaks a game. For a spell deathmatch had some good matches, Co-OP was OK, but you know, the last year or so... It's gotten dead.. Like really dead... Developers have failed to fix crucial issues in multiplayer, instead choosing to go for the low hanging fruit of DLC/New blocks.  The lack of any meaningful changes in Multiplayer has turned it into a Ghost Town (queue The Specials... This town, is coming like a ghost town) Check the number of hours I have in this game.. 

The details:

Let's start with Co-op.

The biggest issue with Co-Op is the lack of control a host has over the game.  It's like having rude guests over for dinner, and never being able to do anything about them.  They come in, eat all your food (use all your blocks) They decide what you have in the cupboard isn't good enough so then they steal your wallet, and spend all your money at the store.  They don't buy Eggs, milk, and flour.. No, they buy throat Lozenges (First GSO wheel) Finally, they put everything out on the lawn, and set it on fire (lose your blocks by dying)

It's super annoying.  All you can do is kick them, but they can rejoin.  There is no ban. 

Oh, and world border.  Someone can join and not move, holding you back from your next mission.

Deathmatch isn't a game of skill, it's a game of "Who can dominate with the biggest tech?"  People will spawn, put blocks into inventory, die, rinse, repeat until they have enough blocks to build something unbeatable.  Then they'll just annihilate everyone else cart blanch. 

Finally, let's get to the Single Player campaign.  It's just not that good.  It's repetitive.  Crafting is optional  once you have autominers.

The game started off great, and 7 years is enough time for the authors to fix things that are broken in multiplayer.  There's other crafting games that have come along since then that sort of keep my interest, but I'm starting to get really bored of TerraTech.

Updated: 8/29/2016

3 months after my initial review, it's time for an update.

Stability issues have been worked out for the most part.  Once in a while I might get a crash, but the game politely asks me if I want to save and submit a bug report and lets me keep playing.

At the heart of it, this game is Mad Max meets Mechwarrior.   The gameplay reminds me of some older DOS games I used to play, and it's a genre that I haven't seen done right in a vehicle game in a while.    A lot of these games had fixed hardpoints, and fixed body types.  TerraTech's building system let's you build pretty much anything the wheels can support.  

You initially start out with what's called a "Cab".  You get a starter gun and some wheels, now you're off to rebuild your war machine.  Initially the game starts you off on small, equal opponents.  You pick their parts after defeating them, attatching them and increasing the firepower (and weight) of your vehicle.   Parts come from various manufacturers, each avaliable after leveling up.  

Eventually you find the singularity unit, and the store.  Now the real fun begins.  You mine some resources, and make enough to start building a base.  Drop your singularity by some destroyed enemy parts, and it sucks it into your inventory. (I like leading them back to it) The base blocks are very functional, and there is a pretty easy to use conveyor system for moving things to parts of your base.   Several blocks chained together can increase the value of your mined resources by refining them, then using the refined materials to make new blocks that you can sell.

Through refinement or purchase, you gain additional "Ai" units.  (Protip.. Use wheels that keep them slow.) Now you plop one of these on your first creation, and start working on a second, or you can just let the little Ai cabs run around your feet with their pew pew shots.  Your choice.

Good game design has a few elements.  It has to reward the player into playing the game correctly, and Terratech does.  At some point your best car will have slow wheels (so minerals don't drop) a battery to keep a shield and repair bubble charged, and some tractor blocks in a t shape with a generator in the middle.  This way you just have to mine the oil, or knock down a tree to keep your shields charged.  Now you can really start dishing out the damage.

*Pros*
Great concept based on an older genre.  Could easily be called "The most flexible" of this genre
Intuitive gameplay that leads a player towards playing the game right.  Great design.
Great physics and mechanics

*Wishlist*
 
There's a few elements of the game that I think can be improved:

SCU Unit: It's sort of a minor annoyance to have to move an SCU near parts.  Why not have 
each cab with a built in SCU unit?  As long as the cab stays parked for an extended period, it starts collecting parts.  Another side benefit?  Less parts that have to be drawn.

Infinite Deployment Consoles:  The deployment console should always be avaliable.  I usually buy a few before heading into a new area, but I do forget to once in a while.  It would be nice to always have them on hand.  I don't mind paying for them, it's just annoying to drive back to another deploy console to get another pocketful.

Flight:  I don't like the "autoswitch" between modes.   If I have shift held down, then for all intents and purposes I should be in flight mode.

Radar/Flight: I think the Flight radar needs to be more like a jet fighter HUD that gives me a little green "Lock On" triangle overlayed in my viewfield.  When I'm trying to strafe units, the current radar doesn't help me much.

Multiple Unit selection:  Would love to be able to select multiple units/cabs the way you do in most RTS's. 

Unit right click context actions:  If I right click a blank area of a map in RTS games, the AI assumes I mean, "Move to this point"  If I have a harvesting unit and right click on a resource, most RTS's know to "Harvest" and if I right click an enemy, it knows to "Attack"

Unit grouping: Assign unit to a group

Hotkeys Hotkeys Hotkeys:  
Ctrl-a (Select all visible units) 
Left Click + Ctrl (add unit to selection) 
Ctrl-Z Undo
Ctrl + 0-9 = assign selected to group
Ctrl + H = Selected Harvest nearest
Ctrl + G = Selected Attack nearest

You get the idea.

Conclusion:  This is one of those early access games where the developers are listening, and coming through on their promises.  I would support this studios next endeavor after Terratech.   If they can ever make this work multiplayer, it's going to be amazing.  Get it now while it's cheap.

8/29/2016 Removed:

 ""This is an early access game, so instead of knocking it for instabilities, hats off to the dev's.  It's been years since I've had a game that completely cripples my system during a crash to the point where I need to perform a hard reset.  Bravo!""

""That being said, let's get into the meat and bones of TerraTech.""

""Other than the crashes that need a hard reset, none.  Can't wait for it to get stable.""

TerraTech is an open-world sandbox game with unique game play. Players must gather resources such as minerals and plants to build and customize their own vehicles, which can then be used to explore the game's world and gather more resources. The game's physics-based mechanics allow for a variety of creative and unique designs, making each vehicle feel distinct and personal. Another strength of TerraTech is its depth of customization. Players can customize and upgrade their vehicles with a variety of weapons, tools, and modules, allowing for a tailored game play experience. The game's crafting system is also deep and intuitive, with a variety of resources and components to discover and utilize. one potential downside of TerraTech is its lack of direction. The game can be overwhelming for new players, with little guidance on how to progress or what goals to pursue. Additionally, the game's pacing can be slow at times, with long periods of resource gathering and building required to progress. TerraTech is a unique and enjoyable sandbox game with impressive customization and mechanics.

It's a relaxing build em up and shoot em up type game, with random AI bots that spawn as you complete quests for the different factions, and each faction has their own special blocks and parts which can be mixed around.
There's a bit of factory type mining and manufacturing to earn in game currency to buy blocks from the little kiosks scattered around the map, or craft your own from the resources.

It plays like another free roam battle bot game, but with the ability to create little mobile bases, and turrets or make an AI buddy that follows and guards your back.

The multiplayer Co-op is especially fun as you and friends share the resources and explore the map together.

10/10 would recommend if you enjoy building and battling little robots.

Nice game in general, sometimes it crashes with no expected reason, but it auto-saves frequently, so that's not a problem at all. Maybe you get overwhelmed with all the blocks that are in this game, because they have added so much since the early days. Another problem is you get for example fly-blocks before you even get the quest "learn to fly" so there is no real linearity and the real story missions you have to do always make you drive 5 km. You also can get stuck with those filler quests like "hunt down enemies" if you don't move your home trading station from time to time. 

Considering the above listed problems I would still recommend the game to anyone who likes to play a game where you build your own vehicle and fight against others (just AI in Campaign). Just switch it up from time to time, try to craft your blocks and not buy them for example and don't only do quests. They are there for progress and if you want to progress through the ranks. As I said, switch it up unless you want to be bored to death at some point.

An easygoing building, exploration and resource collection game with plenty of opportunity to make all kinds of weird and varied constructions. Want to make small lightly armoured attack vehicles? Easy peasy. Colossal monstrosities which are more building than vehicle, which you can anchor and turn into mobile processing factories? Highly recommended. Fliers, hovercraft, VTOLs and anything in between can be built together using attractive themed blocks from different factions.

There's a sandbox mode to have fun with, or you can play through a simple but varied enough freeroam campaign with various side missions to introduce you to the factions, unlock blocks and create bigger and more elaborate machines. Vehicle construction and combat is less in-depth compared to competitors like Scrap Mechanic, Trailmakers and From The Depths, but the focus on improvising, scrapping, harvesting, fighting and rebuilding your techs is a compelling way to spend several hours at a time.

If you're a fan of automation games, the crafting system in this game is a hard pass. The game clearly cant handle a late-game refineries that can manufacture what you need. If you are working on an active crafting building, the game can lag for several seconds at a time each time you place a block. A late game block can pause your factory, but unpausing your factory will cause that lag spike. When you unpause, sometimes assemblers will refuse to take on new blocks. For a fully released product, the amount of freezes and bugs is incredibly disappointing.

The common theme with these types of games is substance. There is no real goal or objective and the game goes from exciting when finding new parts/technologies to boring almost instantly when you realize that getting the best tech makes the game somewhat pointless. There isn't anything exciting to find in the world, so exploring is pointless, there are no rpg elements, the game just ends when you level everything up and its not really satisfying. Great I can build super powerful techs now, but there is no point to having them because there is nothing in the game that you need them for. I hope that changes because I could really see my self spending hundreds of hours in this game, but at the moment its not worth buying unless you will be satisfied with just building machines over and over that have no functional use in the game.

65 hours at time of writing.

On balance, I can't recommend this game.  It's been "ok".  The beginning is fun, with a rather rapid upgrade journey into some beefy tanks that destroy the enemies in a satisfying way.  The mid-to-late game is a drag, and not fun at atll.

Main issues:
- crafting sucks.  It is a tedious, slow, frustrating exercise in trial-and-error that, when you finally get it working, takes ages to produce very little.  It's entirely skippable (and you should)
-base-building is like crafting, on a grander (and more frustrating) scale.  And, frankly, there's no reason to ever return to your base, as missions take you elsewhere in the map
- missions suck.  It's like WoW "kill 10 boars".  All the time.  
- tech design sucks.  Yes, I know, that's what the game is all about.  Building a tank (car with guns and optional armour and non-optional shields/repair and more guns) is easy enough, although there's no in-game info on what the block values are (weight, health, armour, etc) - you have to wiki everything.  Even damage is arbitrary, and the in-game scale does NOT align to the wiki damage for weapons.  But the real pain-in-the-ass is when you get into hovercrafts, or anti-grav, or planes, or god-help-you helicopters.  The build for these is just impossible with an amazing amount of (hours and hours of) trial and error to find out what works and what doesn't.  Basically, it nearly all doesn't.  Throw a couple of propellers together with some blocks and some flight adjustment (and some more flight adjustment, and some more flight adjustment), play with the weight distribution, add some more flight adjustment and you have something that flies...sideways...or goes upside down at launch...or doesn't turn...or turns like a ballet dancer on speed.  It is, frankly, far, FAR harder than it should be.
- story sucks.  There isn't one, basically.  There's a few campaign missions that are procedurally generated, except for a couple of short story arcs, none of which are anything other than simple "go here kill this get that" missions.
- reddit is dead for this game.  I don't think anyone plays it anymore.

Buy it at 70% off price, for a few hours of fun.  Don't expect too much.

I got this game back in 2016 on my shitty Asus laptop that could barely run Minecraft. Because of how bad it was I had to decrease the quality to its lowest and run the game at the lowest resolution, it was literally just a small box on my screen, yet somehow in some way this was still one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played and put a lot of hours into it. I still find myself coming back to this game after months or years of not touching it, then find myself playing the game for another 15-20 hours. I really gotta thank Jacksepticeye, Lathland/Lathrix, Blitz, Drae, and SpyCakes for introducing me to this game, y'all made my childhood awesome.

Terratech is great. There are so many ways to build something and many ways to improve it. I will admit though, the learning curve can be a bit steep in some portions of it, but it is satisfying to finally make that plane or tank or airship that functions and is efficient.

2000 hours later, still pretty good, though has managed to pick up even more bugs than it has fixed

1000 more, it's held up modestly. Still has many of its old bugs but the team seems more promising towards what they have planned for the future. I really base most of my experience from multiplayer, which is an inherently buggy and under supported feature, but I still manage to have fun with it. I've also come to realize that this game really doesn't tell you much on what to do or how to do it, which lends to it being very open for the creative mind to be free and make what you want. It can feel somewhat limiting giving its block system, but at the same time there are such a wide variety of parts you can have that cubes will seem like foreign shapes in an instant. If you really want to get into this game for its pvp aspects, I may know a thing or two since basically all of my hours are dedicated to it, but overall it's not meant for this game - "we" (me and some others) make it work. One of the major issues is that this game isn't particularly well suited for very large builds given its lack of CPU multithreading (one core for attachment points one core for everything else) and that there aren't any natural threats within the larger scale, hence why I enjoy pvp since you can meet people who are both dangerous and are just as capable as you are. Granted, finding a good fight is extremely rare since most of the game's population is children. 

Anyways, building things or recreating real things is quite fun even if it isn't 100% accurate or what you wanted. In the end, you're left with something you made and can be proud of, which is certainly how I feel about most of my ships and whatnot I've posted to the workshop.

TLDR; A decent pickup on a sale.

Its a very good concept, Minecraft meets Factorio with giant robots. What else could you ask for? Build anything you want, see it working, fighting, or falling apart. This game offers a diverse pallete of building blocks, and it seems to be growing with updates. Speaking of which, although they are few and far between, and sometimes have contents of questionable quality, the game did improve over many years of its development, which makes me happy. Lets move to the "questionable" features.

The quest system seems unpolished, grindy, has a lot of unnecessary dialouge, and feels like it was made for an audience of 3 year olds. The main questline is somewhat boring and stale, while the random bounty missions are basically nothing different from killing a regularly spawned enemy. The side quests are fine, and sometimes interesting, but the dialouge is sloppy again.

The game allows you to build on the fly, quite literally, while youre driving, flying, or fighting, you can adjust any part of your machine however you want. This can be handy to pick up blocks that were damaged and fell off of you, but it can be annoying to accidentally pick up the 1 block that holds up half of your robot, and see it fall apart. Luckily, there is an undo button, and you can save a kind "blueprint" of your robot to summon it later, if you have the necessary blocks. Alternatively, you can enter a "build mode" which levitates your machine above the ground and lets you slowly move and turn around if you are in a sticky situation, without any other movement options for example.

This section is about my favorite part of the game, so it deserves to be quite a bit longer, be prepared. You can craft almost any block using fabricators, there is one for each faction, and of course they are blocks that can be placed on your robot as well, which can craft their corresponding blocks. You can only use them while anchored to the ground, so a stationary or a hybrid base is recommended. But dont be hasty, even if this is the most overpowered and fun part of the game, you still need to collect AND refine resources for the fabricators. Where do you find them? Everywhere. See that tree? You need it to make a wheel. That blue rock? Yeah, its needed for something too. Luckily, if you dont want to wander around the world collecting random resources, some of them have a mining node under them, which can give a substantial amount of resources, and the rest of the types can be bought in a shop (or un-crafted from blocks that you bought). Oh yeah, did i mention? If you dont like a block that just dropped from an enemy, you can use a scrapper, which is a similar block to the fabricator, but instead of crafting blocks, it eats them, and gives you back ALL the raw resources! But lets not get too far ahead. You got the resources, what now? You have to transport them to the fabricator, of course, with conveyors! This is where the Factorio part of the game comes. You have to smelt and refine some of the resources, which can get pretty complex if you want to do it fast, and in large amounts. You can store resources in resource silos, which connect to the conveyors, and will send their resources to the fabricators automatically, when they need them. Speaking of what they need, for some unknown reason, each recepie has to be unique. So, if there is a left variant of a block, and a right variant, you bet they will cost a different amount of resources. This is an oversight of whoever designed the recepie system, as, i assume, instead of assigning a cost to each block, they flipped it and associated a block to each cost instead, making it impossible to have blocks that cost the same amount of resources, because the fabricator requests its resources, waits for all of them to arrive, and checks what corresponds to that specific amount of resources, and spits that block out. Oh, and if you got unlucky and accidentally clicked on a wrong block, and cancelled it mid-crafting, any resources that the fabricator ate will be lost forever. You will not get them back, so you better hope that you have enough to craft whatever you want, or have a scrapper to un-do the unfortunate mistake. If you simply dont have enough resources, you can luckily un-anchor and spend as much time as you want grabbing them, as long as your fabricator does not get destroyed, or you dont accidentally disconnect it from your robot by grabbing it and throwing it away.

The soundtrack is nice, but sounds bland after a while. The sound quality overall is good, but its missing variations of the same sound, and can be repetitive after a while.

Multiplayer is a bit janky, although ive seen worse. Some features of the game are not available, but there is not much more to say about it.

There is a lot of glitches and unfinished things in this game. Some are harmless, others can be a big annoyance. And some, very rarely, become a part of the game, and be deemed a feature by the community and the developers, and i like this type of glitches. There has been an update to change the UI of the game completely, turning it into a "mobile pay to win knock-off" look. While i agree that change is necessary in order to make the game better, spending precious development time on a part of the game that was fine, and not even doing a good enough job at it - to the point where it takes less than half a dozen clicks to find the remains of the old UI - is uncalled for.

Lets get past its flaws and look at the good side. As my playtime suggests, this game can be fun, for a few hours, or maybe a few dozen hours, or perhaps a few hundred hours, or if you are really, really into building giant destroyer robots that consume the world and its resources, then, there is a chance, that it will suck you in for even a couple thousand hours.

One of my highest ranking game to favorite and forget. Every time I come back to it, the devs have added a mountain of content to play with. This game is constantly and consistently improved over time, so even if I know a good bit about the game there is still more to explore and try out.

This is one of those games that you will play for a while then come back to after a couple months and do it all again.  Very relaxing and attention absorbing, and late game challenges get progressively harder - if you need a game to forget about life for a bit, this is it. it is long game supportive. Not a ton of games support the 'long term' sort of players. you can collect resources endlessly, build like lego's (and Technic lego's) endlessly.  Its good PG fun. all age ranges can get into this. Its kinda educational too. supports better logic thinking.

It (at this time) still has some code-issues relating to factory building, procedure assembly line setup. I hope the dev gets on fixing those...  but its been a REALLY long time so im not holding my breath.  But there are forums and a discord to talk to others about what to do if your factory assembly line isn't working right.  In my case usually connecting and tearing off refineries often solves my assembly line issues.  (and i don't even mean attaching(& detaching) them to a conveyor. literally just sticking them on some random un-important side or wall or something causes the code to re-check itself and get the 'kinks' out.  So keep that in mind all you big-brain builders *^-^*

Its good for you, good for your kids, good for relaxed-tension  hehe!  I just love it all around. and I've at this point played for 700+ hours!!!!  over the course of 4 years!!!!    so its great stuff!   

Not really hard.  and not overly complex, no real story, Well there is(ish), but its just silly... The initial hurdle is unlocking all the parts.  then its just your long game, of getting enough money or resources or parts.  to last you through all your creative mind can concoct! :D

just be careful letting too many stored-on-field resources build up in open air silos and collectors.  it runs physics for every single thing on the field!  soo  yeah convert those raw resources into blocks and put them in your dimensional storage instead!!    iv you've a rainbow of twirling little pieces suspended in tractor beams or piles... clean it up!!  compress it to blocks pronto!!  then the lag will go away.  *nods*

ok enough reading go play! :D

I bought TerraTech many years ago but only recently really gave it a go. It's a much better game with much more content than the early version I first played. Unimaginable numbers of different blocks and production, mining and factories too now. For a new player I'd say don't get discouraged because you lost a few blocks or died and lost some cool blocks because the game really throws a ton of blocks at you as you progress. You can loot defeated enemies, get rewards for completing quests, purchase and make blocks. Early game you can store blocks away from a store and without a black-hole block just by spawning in a simple saved vehicle (or dragging a cab out of your inventory), attaching looted blocks to it then despawning it again. You can store a lot of blocks just by doing that. The game-loop has you doing quests in order to upgrade your licences so you can purchase and manufacture cooler and more interesting blocks. It's a good system since it gradually introduces new and better blocks to you as you progress and you don't get too overwhelmed by the vast number of blocks there are in TerraTech.

While the game has a ton of potential (really fun at times) a lot of the game mechanics and bugs make it frustrating to play the game past a certain point. Battling other techs is fun, missions keep it entertaining for a while, but once you try to expand your presence in the map and build bases you realise a few things:

-Bases/resource miners don't work if you're out of sight of the base, meaning you can't leave while "auto" miners collect resources, and crafting recipes bug out if you leave during construction
-during crafting, sometimes the crafting process gets confused and resources just pass by indefinitely instead of being taken into component factories
-music/sound effects cut out at times

From what I've seen in forums, and from lack of response to my emails, it seems like the developer has no intention of working with the community to improve or explain any of these things.

This game has come a super long way from when I originally purchased it back in 2015. I have played through this game three separate times over the years now, but something about this most recent play-through that I just finished blew my away. The game feels so complete and oozing with content, and it is still receiving regular free updates. There is so much variety in quest types, techs you can build, enemy techs, etc. You can spend the time to design your own tech or go download something off of the Steam Workshop and plop it straight into your own game. 

The game never feels unfairly difficult, and you can always just reload a save if you get destroyed, but at the same time, the game never feels overly punishing to the point where I felt I needed to do that (but I still definitely did). ;)

Even at full price, I would definitely recommend this game if you enjoy sandbox, open world, exploration games where you can throw in a your own creativity and really make the environment your own. Loved this game.

I've both had this game for awhile, and played it for a decent amount of time to say that this is on my top 5 of favorite games. 

The game is pretty fun to play, so lets start with some of the major positives:
-- The main things that makes this game enjoyable for me is the large amounts of creativity you can fit into your techs from making them crazy strong, complex, or just make them look awesome. Personally I've spent lots of time in the creative mode building cool things that are mostly functional. And if your out if ideas, heading to the workshop and looking around can inspire you.
-- Base Building is another strong point. Making large crafting bases and armored bases is super fun, but this is hampered by the limited building size, but there are ways to get around it.

There are a lot more positives, but those are just two that I think are pretty key to enjoying the game.
Moving onto some of the problems, while being small I think the game has a lot more potential in these areas:

-- First of which is the building limit. I found it quite annoying when I wanted to make a mega base but I can see the reasoning behind it with people who might have performance issues with them.
-- Second is the quests. After doing most of the quests, they become very repetitive and boring, but that usually happens to most games after completing most of the game. But when this occurs is not at the end, but usually when your halfway maxing one of your many licences meaning you get to this point much quicker than you thought.
-- Lastly is while not being to much of a problem is exploration, While the biomes that you come across are all very cool, I think with a game that you can move around a lot in a openly infinite world can have much more to offer here, Though I know its hard to pull well as this game has done.

Those are just some of my personal thoughts and yeah, very much a 10/10 game if you love making unique vehicle's or tech's in this case.

Edit: Co-op needs to have crafting capabilities as this is a huge part of the campaign in my opinion, which it is currently lacking at the minute 
(Its quite easy to find negatives, but the dev team does an awesome job otherwise)

its fun

I also purchased this game on the Playstation Network. 

One of the most fun aspects about this game is constructing vehicles. To start with, you only get a few pieces in limited quantity. As you defeat other vehicles, you can add their pieces to your vehicle. Once you start accumulating more & more pieces, you'll have the ability to construct just about any land or air-based vehicle you can think of. The only problem is when you start getting so many, then you have to be able to store everything. Fortunately, you can begin storing excess pieces at trading stations after a certain point. 

I tend to spend more time constructing vehicles than actually playing the missions. Part of the reason for this is that enemies will spawn in frequently. In most cases, I'll find an enemy that has a piece that I haven't obtained yet or additional pieces that I'll want to add to my inventory. As a result, I almost always have to travel back to a trading station to put my newly acquired pieces into my inventory. 

Some of the drawbacks to this game are:
1. They don't have other camera views. While you have some limited control of the camera by moving it around & zooming in & out to a small extent, you can't really get a sense of where you are dragging pieces to. It would be nice if they had a free camera that would move independently from the vehicle.

2.  Enemies spawn way too frequently. This makes it difficult getting your vehicle to the starting point of a mission with a full battery & repair / shield bubble. Sometimes, multiple enemies will spawn close to you.

3. There are no bodies of water to explore. Which means there are no boats or submarines. It would be awesome if a DLC could be created to add this in. How cool would it be to explore underwater areas or seek out islands?

If you like to use your imagination with your vehicle creations, then this game is for you. On a scale of 1 to 5, I give this game a 4.25.

The singleplayer is truly where the game is at, it has everything from crafting to building bases that auto mine for you to make you tons of BB which is the ingame currency. 

I will say, when i originally bought this game along side my GF, we had plans to play together throughout the campaign and do plenty of crafting. Sadly found out later that the multiplayer aspect of the game is much more limited. After finding out that this is a problem with the hard code within the game itself i can relate a bit to the developers, and do appreciate the work they did to make the multiplayer at least playable, albeit limited is better that not having it.

I would definitely recommend this game to an individual or even a couple, but i will say the singleplayer will give you the full experience. The building aspect of this game is honestly one of the best for its genre. Looking back on games i enjoyed such as "Space Engineers" got me into this genre and i cant get out. This games benefit is its relatively simple building, that can get complex if you want, but can make a perfectly overpowered Tech with a simple design such as a square box with rockets all over it. 

I will say one thing to the developers here, they should consider 1 more faction/corp that's entirely based around walkers. like the at-te walkers from SW or the AATs from SW, or some of the experimentals from Supreme Commander. Would make this game feel complete since its based around Mechs and vehicles through crafting and building, and i feel like there is definitely a hole there since it has just about everything else.

Thank you for reading all of this, I hope it helps you make a decision on rather you should buy it.

"I'll never grow out of playing with Legos", I foolishly said -- "foolish", I say, because I did indeed. Little did I know, Legos can grow up too. What might it look like if they did?
1. Frantically trying to pin blocks back on, while in a frantic firefight where one or both parties is lobbing explosives
2. Rearranging your Tech midfight, because you noticed some of your armor isn't covered by your repair module
3. Drooling in anticipation, as you notice your rival Tech has a particularly rare block, again, while you're still exchanging shells
4. Driving around, doing landscaping, picking up tree debris and rocks, to make a quick buck, because the Shop "Catalog" has some choice parts for sale
5. Ripping apart your battle-tested Tech, because you just realized you can cut out 20% of the bricks if you COMPLETELY rebuild EVERYTHING
6. Only realizing that you're missing one or two critical pieces, only after you've ripped apart all the models you have on the shelf, to mash them together in a twisted, Frankenstien Tech

I, unfortunately, cannot recommend this game. Despite it being fun, it is by the admission of the devs themselves flawed in a fundamental gameplay aspect (fabrication) which they will not fix; this leads to a watered-down multiplayer experience that you are not ever informed of on the Steam page, and must discover on your own after you and a friend have shelled out $50 for two copies of the game. Resource management and fabrication is a not insignificant draw of the single-player experience, and leads to a player being able to access technologies far beyond what they might be able to purchase in a similar amount of time, while allowing for multiple test-runs of a craft that isn't exactly up-to-snuff on your first run with it in case everything goes sideways. In multiplayer, the only way to get parts is either conquest or purchase, and selling any looted items takes an agonizingly long time (Approximately 40 minutes of constant clicking to empty my inventory of unneeded parts for desperately-needed cash). In single-player I could scrap those parts and recycle them into useful materials; in multiplayer I have no choice but to spend an hour or more clicking and waiting at a terminal.

Furthermore, even if you are able to get enough things you want in order to make a build you enjoy, you might not have the opportunity to construct it; the game has 0 building protections, meaning that if you are trying to build a new Tech without any AI guards nearby, you are likely to lose a significant fraction of rare, expensive parts from the build. While it can be satisfying to make a new Tech, it becomes tedious when you are constantly harassed by enemies whilst attempting to build something new. Creative mode is a thing; but I find that I enjoy having to build a new tech for the task at hand when a new issue arises, and the game sucks any fun out of the process when I've been working on a new design for all of 30 seconds and it gets lost to something I cannot hope to escape from.

Unless/until the game either properly explains to new players looking for a full-fat multiplayer experience that they will not be receiving one, or the devs actually incorporate the full host of single-player elements into multiplayer and fix the admitted issues with its mechanics, this review will remain negative.

Do not buy this game for the multiplayer, core features are just not available outside of single player. A general lack of balance as well, enemies spawn at random, no minimum spawn distance so good luck building anything undisturbed. was repeatedly ganked by very low level enemies spawning halfway through building, which ends up losing you parts. Enemy difficulty varies wildly and there's a pretty clear meta of "brick with as many guns as you can fit" so if you want anything more complicated than Mad Max: Bloxorz E-Bullying Edition, look elsewhere. Twenty-five bucks that I'm not getting back.

This game is great for so many reasons, I love the amount of things that you can do, I love the creativity that it inspires in me to create, even if I never really get to it in the game. I honestly think that the story is lacking, but the creating your own path aspect of it is really appealing. Absolutely murdering lower level bots because you're using a flying plane with homing missiles is super fun, and it makes you feel like you did something the game didn't expect. Completely demolishing all of the huge guys with your huge guy also feels extremely fun. The only downside to this is that it does eventually get a bit boring. At a certain point it begins to feel like there's nowhere more to progress to.

TLDR: This game is really great to binge and play for like a week at a time, and then it's replayability is really great, when you get the urge for it.

Overall Rating: 8.5/10

I bought this game a long time ago for about £6.99 and it had a lot of promise, but every time I come back to check it I play for a few hours and give up because of the same janky nonsense that existed pretty much from the start.

Here's the list of annoyances:
1. The vehicles in the game can't traverse mined rocks because for some reason they chose to give them a collision mesh which jams up seemingly all types of wheel. Given the amount of mining in this game, this is particularly annoying.
2. There's no guidance to making a stable vehicle, no clear indicator of the weight of things, so you it's all just trial and error. Good luck designing an aircraft.
3. For some reason they gave the resources physics, which means that if you mine something it'll then immediately collide with your vehicle and flip/lift it.
4. There are lots of weapons and tools with different functions but there are no weapons groups. This would mean you'd have to make a dedicated mining vehicle for example, but you can't because enemies will attack constantly no-matter what.
5. Lazy enemy spawning mechanics mean that you have to engage in very easy combat constantly.
6. There are no well though through design constraints which means basically every vehicle in the game will end up being a ramp with guns on it (even the enemies).
7. There's a crafting system with a factorio-like factory building system, This sounds amazing but it's done so poorly that it can't  really be used. Factories are too complicated to bother with so you'll buy all the parts.
8. The building system is just bad, it's not enjoyable to build vehicles or factories. The random nodes on parts are more annoyance than limitation and if you try to make a base on uneven terrain (like all the terrain) then it's basically impossible.
9. There are too many kinds of resources in a game which has no proper method for dealing with them.
10. There's a weird "anchor" mechanic where your vehicle becomes a base, it makes no sense and again is too janky to use; good luck anchoring your vehicle on uneven terrain.
11. The guns all have auto-aim taking away much of the possible skill in combat, again encouraging a wall of guns rather than a real design.
12. Many of the weapons have ridiculous mechanics which might make for interesting enemies, but certainly aren't useful for the player, leading to lots of useless parts cluttering up the menus.
13. All the boss fights seem to encourage cheesing by out-ranging and other cheap tactics, there's no meaningful indication of difficulty or how well your wall of guns will work before you begin.
14. One of the core concepts of the game is the idea that you kill a vehicle and take its parts to build your own, however they've made that pretty tedious even with the black hole device, because it relies on the "anchor" mechanic which means even when you finally do anchor, it takes about 10 seconds to get all the parts which ruins the pace of the game.
15. You can't put parts in your inventory; you either need the previously mentioned black hole device with 10 second delay or you need to attach parts to an "anchored" block and then right click and put all the parts in your inventory. For a game about salvaging parts this is needlessly tedious.

There's definitely a good game in there somewhere, but this is now a £25 game and no loner in early access. In my opinion it's just not polished enough to consider a release-worthy game yet, needs more time in the oven and more focus on making the core game fun rather than doing the easier tasks like new parts, artwork or missions.

This game is very fun up to a point in progress.  When you are required to do missions for extra parts (instead of being able to destroy other techs / buy them), it goes downhill.  I can understand a bit more challenge, but the way these missions work can be really annoying.  For the entirety of the game, you are encouraged to modify/build your tech to fit your play style, but then you get these missions that force you into incredibly cramped areas or vast open areas against invincible foes (supposed to flee).  The control dynamics can vary greatly depending on size and modules on your tech.  So the sudden shift into requiring all different sizes/types of techs could be smoothed out a lot more in order to gradually require the player to take incremental steps towards the later, much harder/restrictive missions.

TerraTech Review:
  Pros:
  * Base gameplay is easy to pick up and understand, yet has a sense of complexity and nuance. This makes 
     for a very satisfying gameplay loop.
  * Unique and interesting design, allows for the creation of any vehicle/craft using a wide array of voxel 
     blocks
  * Procedurally generated open world sandbox with a mission based system, which forms the foundation for 
     the game's main gameplay loop. Missions allow you to unlock new companies, or progress your status 
     within existing ones, in order to unlock new parts.
  Cons:
   * Sometimes, controls and movement can feel janky and unresponsive. However, this is often times a result 
      of an error within your build, since many factors such as, lift, weight, tire diameter, and weight distribution 
      all have a varying impact in the effectiveness of your build. Not exactly a con, but I definitely spent most 
      of my first few hours running into every rock and tree imaginable.
   * Rocks and Trees are a huge annoyance if you're using a large tech, since you either destroy the obstacle, 
      damaging yourself, or you stop dead in your tracks surrounded by 20 other rocks in the bottom of a tall 
      valley. In the future it would be cool to see dynamic tires, that function similarly to real life, or a larger  
      focus on suspension articulation, but both of those things are hard to program and not necessary for a 
      game of this style. Overall, I think that travel in this game is satisfying, and often a fluid and easy 
      experience with a good vehicle, however it could still be improved upon. 
   * Multiplayer is missing core gameplay features, yet is still highly functional, stable, and enjoyable while in 
      the multiplayer campaign.
   * AI is hilariously stupid at times, especially when the tech is on your team trying to Follow/Guard while 
      mobile. To solve this, I found that rooted defense turrets around a base was often the go to strategy, and 
      was very reliable.
      means that a part of this game, is basically unusable at times.
  Summary:
  In brief, I would like to talk about my overall thoughts and opinions on the game. However, note that I am 
  not fully finished with the game and the things that it has to offer. I believe that this game is a solid 8/10 , 
  and often impresses me with it's surprisingly good visuals, huge sandbox, and a multitude of other factors  
  that will keep you coming back for more. Although, there are moments where the game shows it's 
  weaknesses, they are far and few between, and I give major credit to Payload Studios and their team for 
  their dedication and creation of a very good product.

I highly recommend this game! It's got quite a bit of content, the variety of pieces and parts is huge, and you can build some really unique stuff! The artsyle is wonderful, and the crafting system is genuinely pleasing. I have a lot of good things to say about this game, even if crafting is STILL missing from co-op and updates are infrequent. There's plenty there already to make it fun!

This genre is filled with P2W garbage and always-online stuff, so I'm really, really happy to point out that the monetization here is PURELY cosmetic! There's workshop support, so you can get mods, player-made builds, and even skins, and there's procedural terrain, meaning you can travel for miles.

I love to make original builds and play around with the game's mechanics, it's overall quite fun and I rate it an 8/10!

However, I do want to point out the cons, which I don't think amass to much but I'll let you be the judge: The enemies start to become trivial after you layercake enough weapons, however if you let your guard down, they will eventually crack through your shielding if you don't pay attention to how much battery you've got left.

I think you start to encounter more powerful enemies the further you progress or the farther you travel, so I'm not sure how that works. The UI is great, but there are issues with the camera, bugs with the UI itself, and other things such as 1920x1080 support being awkward (not supported in the Unity startup window but being supported in-game? what), other small bugs like that which can get really annoying. Also, not being able to press 3 keys at once!

Despite no crafting in co-op and all these annoying little bugs that add up, I still love this game and I still absolutely recommend it. What makes that possible is this game's personality. You can tell the developers of this game genuinely love what they do and what they've made, it shows in the atmosphere, in their updates themselves (despite infrequency), and in the game overall. This game has personality, this game has variety, this game has funny big car go boom. It's great!

Thank you Payload Studios for making something that gives me hope for this P2W balance issue infested build-your-own-vehicle genre once more :>

If you asked me if terratech was a fun game I would simply answer with a yes. Despite the fact the game is fun I also think it is majorly flawed. I am not too sure why I enjoy the game as much as I do with how many problems it has but I would like to go over some of the problems in this review just so you know what you could be getting yourself into. 

Lets start with one of the biggest flaws to the game, difficulty. This game is not difficult AT ALL, and i would love for the devs to, at the very least, add more enemies to the game. As of right now the only challenge you will face is from the Hawkeye faction and the missions (they are rarely difficult but you can run into some really tough ones). Even by the time you run into Hawkeye there is a fair chance you have outpaced them and are already stronger than them. Most of the randomly spawning enemies are incredibly weak, so they are only ever a threat in the early game. 

That is another one of the major problems with terratech, there isn't much to the late game. Once you have all the factions unlocked you can easily pave through enemies like they are nothing, because they don't seem to scale. The only enemies that scale with your tech (at least to my knowledge) are the invasions which are player made techs that can occasionally drop down near you. Even when they are threatening you can kill them easily if you have heavy hitting weaponry or are just flying. The late game of terratech is mainly just building and testing vehicles, aka the same thing you could get in creative mode. There is never a major threat to you in this game past the mid game.

Going back to enemy techs, we have the enemy ai. There are only ground enemies (for the most part atleast, it is said in the wiki that there are flying enemies and they are just really rare but i have yet to see one for myself), because the devs just haven't made the ai work with planes. The ai try to use car mode when they can because they aren't built to fly. The lack of flying enemies is somewhat sad because i imagine they could add some much needed difficulty if given the right weapons.

I've been saying a lot of negative things about the game, and i haven't even gotten through all of it (the balancing for certain weapons is just sad, and co-op is a insult), so why am i giving the game a positive review? Honestly I'm not too sure, but the game is still fun. Even with the bad ai, garbage difficulty, and lack of late game content, it is still a fun game. I think its a mixture of simple, yet fun, combat along with the easy building that generally isn't too frustrating, or the memorable techs you meet during missions. I have a fun time playing this game and from time to time I still play it, and I just hope the devs make the game at least a little more interesting. 

This is the most effort I've put into a review (even if it is still a shit review), and the reason i put so much effort into it was because i really want people to know what problems this game has before they play, but i also want to say that it IS NOT a bad game (as long as you don't play co-op). Maybe the devs will fix some of the issues and maybe not, honestly I will still play the game either way.

This game is a block based vehicle building and combat game, with a bunch of other mechanics like crafting, buying/selling, and missions.

[h1]The good:[/h1]
+ Great campaign mode, which offers a great deal of freedom. Think of it like Minecraft's survival mode.
+ Creative mode, build whatever your heart desires.
+ Tech snapshots (saving your vehicles) are great. Snapshots are cross-save, cross-game mode ways of transferring your builds from one place to anywhere else. It works with steganography, which is taking an image of your tech, then encoding your tech's data in the image itself. It's a really cool method, which also gives you a preview for everything.
+ Actively maintained and updated by its loving development studio.
+ Great community.
+ No paywalled content, only cosmetic skins and the R&D DLC, which is a very specialized testing environment (which, in my opinion, has lost most of its use with the advent of creative mode, because you mostly just build big stuff in there :P)
+ Balance is overall pretty good.
+ There is a great variety of blocks of all kinds.
+ You can build ground techs, flying techs, and even hover techs, and also bases.
+ The music is absolutely banger.
+ Good replayability.
+ Limited multiplayer support.
+ The block inventory system with SCUs, and how it was updated that you now always have access to it instead of only when you have an SCU placed somewhere. It's well implemented.
+ Each corporation (think of them as factions) is well defined, characteristic, and lovable.
+ Twitter integration for getting the techs of other people in your own game.
+ Workshop support for both skins, techs, saves, and mods! Of course, mods are not as straightforward to install as clicking the subscribe button on steam, but mods are never easy.

[h1]The depends-on-the-person-playing-the-game:[/h1]
~ Making money takes a little effort, you won't make enough money by passively killing enemies and doing missions.
~ Completely rebuilding your tech as you reach high enough grades with different corporations (tldr leveling up a bunch) could be potentially divisive (I personally enjoy it), but it won't happen all too often.
~ Lots of enemies, lots of fighting. Peace is not too easy to come across, but it's achievable.
~ Tooltips of blocks and missions contain some lore alongside tips on using specific blocks, but it's mostly just fluff. I recommend reading them.
~ Travel distances aren't short. You'll have to take your time preparing for, and during traveling.
~ Story missions (not repeatable ones) leave permanent changes in your world in the form of buildings, environments, etc. They are fairly spread out in case you don't want them, however this contributes to longer distances.
~ Tech archetypes. Combat techs are almost always a bunch of batteries, shields, and a front side full of guns. Miners are mostly drills with few guns and a lot of resource pads. Combining tech types is useful, but against a few particularly brutal purpose-built enemies, you're going to be at a huge disadvantage.
~ Enemies drop a lot of blocks. Picking them up is good, but a little tedious.
~ The AI is acceptable. It's not great, but it is not bad by any means.
~ The implementation of some things are funky, but that's a given with every game, really.
~ The newest corporation, Reticule Research, is not entirely finished.

[h1]The not good:[/h1]
- The very late game is partially dominated by who makes the first strike due to the large amount of firepower of high tier guns.
- The previous issue is exacerbated by the existence of a few particularly powerful weapons (namely the Megaton Cannon and missile launchers). These are relatively small weapons with long range and a nearly disproportionate amount of firepower for its small size. The number of enemy techs featuring these weapons have been cut back, but these weapons are still troublesome to encounter, and since your own tech is not limited in any way, you can plaster on as many of these weapons as you want.
- There are very few mid-game enemies. Almost all enemies are early game, endgame, or made for a challenge mode called sumo mode, which gives you a limited set of blocks to make a tech that can push or destroy an enemy made from the same stuff. These techs are slow, fairly large, and generally not well armoured, but most importantly, very same-y. When you fight these, Geocorp battle music plays (they have the largest hull blocks, and sumo techs use a bunch of those), so better get used to those 2 tracks. At least they are pretty good, but repetition and music doesn't mix too well.
- If you read this far, have a cookie
- Past the first two grades of GSO, battery power is basically your health: it keeps your repair and shield bubbles operational. If you run out of power, your tech is left undefended and unable to repair any damage it sustains, which leads to your blocks falling off (if you're lucky!), or getting obliterated.
- Adding onto the issue of battery power being mandatory for survival if you plan to fight, death is potentially pretty punishing. When you die, you have the option of rebuilding your previous tech from blocks in your inventory (buying blocks you don't have, which gets expensive very quickly as you get larger), taking control of one of your other techs in the vicinity, or if that's not an option, get a grade-specific GSO tech for free that's only really good for driving back to safety.
- Volatile blocks are very hard to acquire. You have to craft and buy the majority of the ones you get, because when you destroy the cabs (main block, if it dies the whole tech dies) of enemies, some of their blocks blow up, which in the case of volatile blocks, damages other blocks around it, and since these blocks tend to be placed near each other, it's rare that these kinds of blocks survive, especially in groups of more than 1.

[h1]Final thoughts and opinions:[/h1]
Don't let the negatives deter you from the game! They largely apply only to specific in-game scenarios, and most can be circumvented one way or another.
This game is a great deal of fun. How you make your tech decides everything about it: the square-cube law applies to mass and propulsion, which leads to larger techs always being much slower than teeny tiny speedsters. Once you take this into consideration, you also have to think about how much battery capacity you want to squeeze onto your tech. Batteries are vulnerable and heavy, but you must power your shields at all costs... Then you have to move your entire construction, regardless of size, through terrain. Are you gonna go on the ground, will you fly, or will you use a hover tech? Or make the decision of "sod that, I'm downloading the water mod and making a submarine!"? All up to you! Go ahead and get the game, experiment, build a nice crafting base that can make anything, charge your tech in case you run out of power, and defend you! It's a static base, you can make it however you like!

Great game!

It is very relaxing when building your techs and bases but also has a sense of suspense as you don't know when an enemy is going to creep up on you. The fighting aspect is fun and requires some skill as you have to build your tech so that you can effectively kill your enemies as quickly as possible.
The story is well paced and encourages a lot of travelling which stops you from staying in one place and pushes you to go out into unsafe areas, away from the comfort of your base, and test your skills.
The automation part of it is fun as it reduces the amount of manual refining and crafting that you have to do so you can focus on progressing in the story line.

It is overall a very good game and has allowed me to sit down and relax for hours many times in the past.

I very much recommend buying it and giving it a try, its worth it.

Safe to say, TerraTech is one of the best games I've ever played.
Rather than saying it's a "combination of Lego Technic and Guns",
I would say that it's a strange combination of Mindustry and Robotech.

If you haven't heard of either, don't worry -- TerraTech teaches you how it all works.
You build a small tech, kill small techs. Gather the blocks to grow, kill bigger techs.
It's a cycle that keeps you going. The Factorio-level of seratonin and dopamine from annihilating a tech that killed you ages ago is palpable.
And it's very, very tasty.

Safe to say, if you love to collect things, kill things, do missions for other people in an attempt to stand independent as your own prospector, then THIS is the game for you.
