Do not let my hours in this game fool you, this is a moved account, in reality, add 1,500 hours to the hours you see on here. I have been around since the time the game had only 3 corporations and when the megaton cannon was an experimental block.

===   Why you should consider picking up this game or lingering around.   ===

[b]-Potential[/b]
   Terra Tech (TT) has MASSIVE potential! The devs interact with the community CONSTANTLY, and this interaction caused missions like Charlie Watchtower and the Reticule Research (RR) faction to come around and stay around, this is also why we have a form of multiplayer right now. This game is growing like an oak tree, not like a building, adapting constantly and can do so with extreme sensitivity, albeit slowly. The devs are also not afraid to experiment and do radical changes like the new type of missions like Charlie Watchtower and a new faction suggested and supported by the community; Reticule Research. This gives the game a lot of possibility for growing and is unlikely to stop for a very... very.. long time.

[b]-Extensive Mod Support.[/b]
   TT is a game that tries to be a lot of things, from mindless combat to organized base building. TerraTech covers so many categories it tends to lack in quality in many. Mod developers however are more than happy to fix those qualities, like the target prediction mod from TerraTech Mod Manager (TTMM) to help with the combat and for just more things to play with, custom block mods found in the workshop. (TTMM is for unofficial mods, the mods on the workshop are official mods supported by the developers directly).
    Payload Studios is very keen on increasing mod support even further in the hopes to have all types of blocks be supported with the official modding tools. You can expect mods to become a part of this game like with other mod heavy games like Stelaris and Forts RTS.

[b]-Great community.[/b]
   As an introvert and someone who is massively insecure, the fact I have began to participate heavily in this game's community in my eyes show it is a wondrous place. There may be only a few of us compared to other games, but we are all good people for the most part and it is because of this that I ever made this review.

[b]-Great developers.[/b]
   The devs of this game are amazing, they interact with the community whenever they can and even keep us posted, although this has lessened over the years. Don't ask why crafting isn't part of multiplayer, it has been answered 5,000 times so the team is a little run-down for direct interaction. We as a player base are given plenty of information about the game by the small dev team but be sure to search for the info yourself first before asking for information. I even interacted with the community to such an extent I was an unofficial community manager and I can say; over the years it has been very enduring to answer the same questions.

[b]-Growing with the game.[/b]
   TerraTech is likely to evolve in a similar fashion to Minecraft. With update after update after update after update, and eventually, a possible rework on some old parts to make them more refined and polished. As someone who joined this game years and years ago from Ssundee's first lets-play of TT, I am confidant in this and it has been quite a ride. I am looking forward to TT's future.
[hr][/hr]
[h1]=== What might deter you from buying this game. ===[/h1]

[b]-Performance demand.[/b]
   TT is a very performance intense game. Many attempts at helping this have been made with varying success but TT is still and will always be a performance intensive game. It is however a lot better than in the past. If you have a decent PC the game will run alright until you really do some big things, like building massive constructs and creating a boarder around your base with nothing but individually built turrets.

[b]-Too many niches.[/b] (Also is responsible for the game's potential.)
   TT tries to be many things, a combat, resource management, fleet building, base building, vehicle building, sandbox, free-roam, adventuring, and roll playing game. As you may expect, the amount of work done in each category had to be distributed throughout. Many areas are a bit low in quality, some more than others, because of this design choice.

[b]-Partially working multiplayer.[/b]
   Keeping this short: Multiplayer has massive limitations, the game was designed to be single player for its first 2 or so years, the multiplayer content is so limited it can be quantified. I would say about 50% of the game's total content is missing in multiplayer player and mainly because of crafting and base building not working on a server and requires essentially an overhaul and rework from the ground up to change this.

[b][u]-Limited Player Experience![/u][/b]
   [i]If I could make a 2nd review it would be nothing but about this. [b]If you are looking for a game you can play over and over again. [u]I HIGHLY discourage picking up TerraTech.[/u][/b][/i]
   Fun fact, after 1,600 hours I barely played this game. After 1,700 I outright retired and the last 194 hours have been gained over the course of [i]2 years[/i]. [b]There is no end game. There is no major goal to work towards, (Avorion is a good example of it done right). There is no access to more challenge for long-time players. There is no sustain of content (I am looking at you, Core Missions! [which are 1-time missions]).[/b] This is made worse by how the 1-time missions are entirely roll play, there are lots of them, are mandatory to complete, agonizing to travel to which makes base building meaningless in the early game, and [i]you can't speed up or skip the monolog of the mission[/i], having to wait a good 30 seconds or so before you can BEGIN the mission that will last 1 or 2 minutes and never play again within that game save.
   I completely ran out of things to do. Unofficial Mods can't help as they can't add custom missions or change the main experience. Official Mods can't help as they only add things, not improve core mechanics. There is no reason to build diligently even in creative mode when nothing will challenge even a poorly built creation and the things that do are [i][u]creative mode[/u] PvP[/i] and [i]Reticule Research core missions[/i] that you can only play once per save.
   I stopped playing because there was nothing to play with. The game is open world but it feels like the world is empty, baron, uninteresting, tedious, and dead. Nothing ever happens. It's like replaying the same day over and over and over again while the game acts like each replay is "a new day". [b]It is not.[/b]

Mixed feelings.  If there was a neutral vote, I would have clicked it.  It does have good game play and a good bit of player freedom and flexible creativity.  It looks aesthetically pleasing too.  Somethings become a bit too repetitive though.  Even as you progress and get better parts, there doesn't feel like there is any real mid or end game feel too it.  It is one thing for the game play progress to slow down, but something about how this goes is something other then grinedy, like even if you do get a new, bigger, more powerful gun, something feels off and lack luster.  It is too easy to get burned out on this game and any reply value melt away.

It feels like a game that is missing something and needs to over come a hurdle before it can become great.  I don't know what that is.  What ever it is, it is making the usual progression and grind seem... off and odd, making it feel weird and unrewarding after time goes by.  what ever is missing, it is having a bizarre effect in the later game that leaves a sense of "meh," as you keep leaving up and building up.

Beautiful and unique game. Quite the class of its own.
Various blocks force the player to think outside the box to every tech design.

However...
NEEDS MORE CAMPAIGN MISSIONS! Absolutely loved the missions with reticule research! Ghosts and tower destruction was the most fun I've had for about a week. Then, nothing much to do after all corporations were maxed out. ...Just sitting in my RR campaign dome base and engineering the heck out of anything I can think of with 20 million block unspent. Also, is it possible to use your own campaign worlds and invite other friends? Would like to play with other people in campaign. But, I also don't see an option to keep it private if I load my own.

Additional:
X - Doesn't run too well on 8GB ram laptop. Required resolution 1280/720 for 40fps (can't really help it)
O - Love the addition of new blocks. However, should add more at a time and include blocks exclusive to some of the missions, e.g. mission where you had to navigate through a maze with ghost RR vehicles (would like to see invisible technology).
O - Few bugs when I first downloaded over 3 years ago (haven't experienced any in the last two years).
X - Where the ocean at?

Not much to say. You can build different styles of techs, ranging from small and speedy, to large scale mobile bases, assuming you have the parts or money to do so. It's too easy to dump your whole day into this game, and I love it. As someone with ADHD as an adult, this game is perfect for zoning out and just creating. There's always something to do, be it upgrading your current tech, building a new one, making a base, hunting down enemy techs, or running quests! This frekking game is 7 frekking years old and the frekking developers couldn't fix / design properly flaws already existing since beginning:

Control air vehicles isn't possible with mouse -> to make matters worse if you turn to hard, you view isn't focussed anymore, meaning you have to use your 3 hand to center your vision; all in favor to pick up new blocks in the middle of the flight to put on your tech *sarcastic* :
Helicopter and Plans have to be balanced with center of gravity, center of thrust in mind to have them actually steerable.

Instead of working on the actual problem, there are just lame workarounds like giant frekking gyroscopes and flight computers and "fixed" weapons with some degree of rotation freedom and auto-aim.

Also there is a bug where component factories ignore resources if higher tech factories need ones to, but already have all they need - they are quick fixes in the internet wich are also 5 years old.

All the developers do is to publish new blocks but ignore the rest - so this game is still beta and did not succeed to evolve past it for frekking 7 years.

In conclusion: Cool idea, but they fail to bring good solutions / designs to the table

It's a pretty reasonable single player game, each time I thought I was coming to the end there would turn out to be more to explore, probably about 60 hours of game play all told. If you only want it for single player there's a lot to recommend this fun game.

Multi player is a massive letdown, I mainly bought this game to play co-op with my son, but I'd say at least half of the game is simply missing in co-op. The production tree is totally disabled, there's no ability to craft items, no advanced materials and a lot of the story missions are simply skipped in exchange for just flat out giving you all the blocks. It's not bad to play a little, but compared to single player co-op it's a massive let down.

Revised review: In general, I'm having fun, though there are some major weaknesses, too.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[h2]1. The control scheme.[/h2]
You look around by holding your right mouse button - but the game still moves the now invisible cursor. Which means once the cursor leaves the game window you suddenly loose all control. When do you most need to turn a lot? In combat. Loosing all control in combat sucks.
There is a way around that - you can bind the cursor to the window in the options. That's better - but still bad, because while you don't loose control, your view still suddenly stops turning, and you need to reposition the cursor on the screen before you can turn anymore.
Overall, this is miserable.

[h2]2. Minimal Information / Bad Communication.[/h2]
I've repeatedly been frustrated by a near total lack of information or badly selected partial information. Examples:

You're first shown the use of fabricators, conveyor belts and conveyor belt filters - which lead to the conclusion that fabricating bases will be terribly complex, span huge areas and be extremely expensive. A few missions later you're shown that fabricators, refineries and silos will manage each other automatically and a manufacturing setup is extremely simple.

Also, some blocks are menufactured not from materials, but components. I've not yet found any codex or description in the game. I've no idea what I need for a block until I've anchored a fabricator and selected the block. [i]Then[/i] I can mouse over the component and see what ressources it represents, but still not how to fabricate it. But some of them are made from other components, too, and you cannot even get a mouse over parts list for those.
Without the ability to produce components most of the long list of parts I could theoretically produce are completely unavailable to me. By now I've found out (from a YT video) that I need another block to produce them, but no idea how to get that. I've made multiple levels on my main license and gotten a few new ones, but in the game there has been no mention of components at all outside the icons shown in the parts list. So the first time I needed components to do something was barely a few hours into the game, but there has been no explanation or availability tens of hours later.

The order in which you are introduced to concepts is often suboptimal, you're often left to guess or ponder implied misinformation only to be shown/taught the real info much to late.

[h2]3. Glitches[/h2]
An older version of this review complained about the fact that constant combat made designing bigger vehicles and even simple bases next to impossible - because I was constantly interrupted by enemies spawning within aggro radius of me and attacking. This went on like that for a couple of hours. After I gave up, thoroughly frustrated for the night, that never happened again. Now enemies only spawn at some distance, and it's only on occasion they actually attack the base anymore, which makes everything a lot better.

On the other hand, my defense turrets regularily get attacked (and sometimes damaged or destroyed) - not by enemy techs, but by vegetation. Trees respawn into anchored tech, which triggers a violent collision detection, damaging blocks, sometimes destroying them, occasionally transforming them into the Leaning Tower because suddenly they're anchored at a 30° angle.


[h1]The Good[/h1]
Ignoring moments in which you'll bang your head against the above mentioned weaknesses, it's fun. Lots to tinker and experiment and do this and try that. So far, I haven't come across an obvious, ultimate design to follow, the lack of which is great game design to create a big, varied creative space for different builds.

It's not great (yet), but it's good. If you have a bit of patience for the downsides and you like silly humor, tinkering, creativity and the constant stream of small rewards, you'll be happy to spend some time with TerraTech.

So i tried this game during the free week, figured I'd get a few hours out of it at least.. What an under estimation!

Happily parted with my money (£10gbp on sale) and foresee blasting past 100 hours since i haven't even started making aircraft yet. 

Haven't tried the multiplayer yet, don't really feel the need to get my creations blasted to hell and don't have any friends that play to try co-op.

Gameplay is your basic mmo style grind.. harvest for cash, missions for tech unlocks... how you choose to do the grind however is somewhat up to you.. a small fast buggy that runs laps round big slow techs, or a big lumbering tech that is covered with so many guns that you're clearing everything in sight with one press of the trigger? A big super-harvester that grabs everything in sight or a flying craft and cherry pick the good stuff?

Physics for car balance/behaviour seems great, with my poor design choices being the only reason i get stuck.

If you're looking for a fairly casual time sink with a lego-like familiarity to the building style, definitely give this game a try.

Now for the flip side of my love for the game, not complaints, just something i wish i could do.

Vehicle designs are locked into a 'single platform' design due to no hinged sections.. the inclusion of these and a more complex key-bind would allow for articulated platforms for manoeuvrability, or limbed techs with some sense of control.. as it stands i feel most drill and laser types are very niche use cases. (may well be planned for future update, or just flat out impossible within the engine... just something i'd thought about.. keyboard/flightstick combo for full mech-controlling immersion... yes please) :D

Like so many Early Access games before it, TerraTech have effectively gone stale in progress.
While it may recieve updates every other month or so these updates are negligible in terms of new content.
A few new blocks here, a new paid for skin there, but nothing substantial.
Sandbox Multiplayer is effectively vestigial as it still doesn't have crafting, and a severely limited 'tether range' that keeps players in relatively close proximity to eachother.

The game is a decent enough timekiller, but at the current pace of significant new developement that appears to be all it will ever amount to.

Fun to start and progress, but the game become tedious fast.
Pros:
- Pretty simple but satisfying vehicule building
- Decent range of movement types. Flying with the small aircraft you are given is very nice
- Great tools to manage multiple designs

Cons:
- Navigation can become very frustrating. Some biome transitions are almost impossible to traverse without hovercraft
- Controls are often frustrating and unresponsive
- Late-game, enemies do not pose any challenge unless they surprise you with a large group
- Enemy design do not seem to evolve past a certain point. It then become more difficult to start working with more interesting blocks that enemies could have dropped.
- Fight strategy are very simple, mass long range guns or rockets to the front and keep facing forward
- Missions get very repetitive. There are only a few kind of basic missions, with corporations having at maximum one kind of unique mission. The quality of developper-crafted missions vary a lot, but many are often frustrating to play
- New blocks added through updates are only available through random chance drops after clearing basic missions

Fun and immersive little Captain Forever-em up in 3D where the most powerful weapon of war is gargantuan cruise-missile toting flying factory-tractors. 

For a cube-stacking sandbox game it has a surprising amount of things to do, though even this one is cursed by the inevitable creeping realisation of where the boundaries lie. There's still a fair few dozen hours of rearranging the former corpses of your enemies into machines of destruction, and even a little bit of factory automation.

Fucking love it.

Graphics: Cartoony and bright. The vehicles mostly look like toys.

Sounds: Great, the vehicles sound like toys, do so most of the weapons

Combat: Basic. weapons autoaim towards the nearest enemy, but if you have multiple enemies, you can middle click to select one. There is a wide variety of weapons from the different corporation factions. Building a vehicle that plows into the enemy? You can. homing missiles? Got that. want to set up a bomber that drops a massive pile of bombs. Yeah that can be done too.

Crafting: You can build your own "Techs" which are vehicles, bases, turrets, etc. You can even build aircraft. Parts have weight which will affect your vehicle. Slap a tank turret on a car with tiny wheels, and it's not going anywhere. You can build cars, tanks, helicopters, hovercraft, and even a wierd monster truck/helicopter/bomber hybrid if you want to. You can take what remains of a destroyed enemy vehicle and use it yourself or scrap it for materials.

Story: There's a story, but it's not that interesting. IT can be ignored. This is a sandbox game.

All in all? Don't get this game, there are better games in this genre elsewhere, even besiege is better lmao.

I wish there was a maybe button because this is a very fun game to play with lots to offer but there are some pretty huge problems being ignored that will most likely be patched with time but this game isn't early access and therefor is claiming to be finished otherwise I would have recommended the game.

First off, the AI is awful. There is no AI for helis or planes, just for ground vehicles and hovercraft but even this is poor. Kind of makes a lot of the steam game images misleading because if you're planning on building the perfect jet for dog fighting, you're out of luck, ground attack only.
The AI they do have for ground vehicles is shockingly bad. They do nothing but drive in a completely straight line towards you shooting, they don't navigate obstacles like rocks, trees or cliffs. They just drive straight into/off them. They also only activate once you're painfully close. They're visible far before the AI switches on and they just sit there stationary until you get close enough. There are a lot of weapons that out range this AI on trigger so you can just cheese most enemies by shooting them from a distance and they just sit there and take it without moving.
Friendly tech AI is also pretty basic as only the guard/follow option is available meaning you can't programme techs to harvest resources etc, just either follow you around or guard a location (if you anchor the tech like a turret that is, you can't have a vehicle patrol an area).

Crafting is also (by the developers own admission) janky at best. It's very awkward to try and place things properly, particularly auto miners which for seemingly no reason require you to pick them up and place them over and over and over until you find the sweet spot and it finally works. 
I actually did my campaign run without crafting a single part (except for mission required crafting) and just using the buying stations. I just set some mining stations up for money (which is very tedious and frustrating to do as it is) and bought everything I needed negating the system pretty much entirely.
Oh, and there is no crafting at all in multiplayer because fuck you.

The building system is very unique and does a lot of things right but it is also infuriating to use at times. Seemingly basic utilities like mirror mode, copy/paste, a proper undo, moving multiple blocks at once (for example a wing that contains multiple parts) are all missing. You work with 1 part at a time, click and drag and that's it. 
The rotation system is pretty un intuitive as you have 1 single button to control the axis AND the attachment point relative to the tech, no rotation or movement axis drag, meaning sometimes you will sit spamming the button to get finally get the right angle and attachment point of which there are sometimes 10-15+ variations and if you miss it you have to spam press and go through them ALL again.
If you try to move a part that is supporting others all those parts fall off, this means if you spend 10 minutes making a wing with lots of parts and attachments then when testing the craft realise it's weight and lift is off, you can't just move the wing as a whole. You have to break it all off and start the wing again in the new location from scratch and then do the same on the other side. Trying to make large vehicles with lots of complex parts is a nightmare because to make things symmetrical you have to do it all manually.

It's also pretty buggy. The sound would randomly bug and stop working for around 10-15 minutes at a time then come back for no reason. Nothing would fix this, I tried loading a new tech, reloading my save and restarting the game but all that would work was just to ignore it and wait for it to come back. I also experienced several crashes in my 68 hours which isn't so bad but not so great either.

In conclusion I've mentioned a lot of negative things here and I want to say I don't hate the game, I actually really like it and there are many great things about the game (which you can read about in all the other reviews) but I feel I had to mention this stuff because it goes mostly un-noticed.
As mentioned, I would be willing to overlook all this if this game was in early access and when playing at first I thought it was and I was shocked when I checked the steam page and saw it was not. Sadly though, the response from the developers to many of these issues is simply that to fix them or add them would be too complex and that they may as well make a new game to include things like this.
This excuse I heard in response to AI aircraft, resource collection AI, moving multiple blocks in build mode, copy pasting blocks and having crafting work in multiplayer and it's frustrating as a player to hear things that would be a huge quality of life improvement for the players and things that are standard in many other games of this type just being dismissed in favour of a new skin pack.

I wish there was a maybe button because you'll likely have a really great time playing this game despite these issues but I feel this had to be said.

Starting out is incredibly difficult (no difficulty settings) and you HAVE to stack up your resources because you never know when a bigger and badder "tech" will come up. Your guns cannot hit shit, somehow what should be a mobile setup with good dps is absolute trash. Whenever you've lost some blocks you basically gotta rebuild the whole thing (and mind you - that is going to happen a LOT (you CAN create builds, but realistically they work only once you've gathered enough and discovered/unlocked a variety of blocks)). Progress is slow, meaning it will take a LONG time before ANY decent blocks become available but if you don't invest countless hours practically consequently - you won't know what shit does what, making you incapable to do just about anything.

Other games require skill gained through time, like multiplayer fps games. in some you are able to simply jump in, usually rpg/story driven games. With this one you HAVE to do extensive research and experimentation to get things going, basically - minecraft but ONLY the redstone stuff. It's awesome when it works, but getting it working... You gotta watch vids, but then - what's the point...

This game can be a huge hit for you if you want to find one single game to drop endless hours into, however other than that the game is FAR too complicated. Similar to Terraria - you have to do research before playing the game, however you can play Terarria without it, while this game without the right amount of hours and knowledge will be agonising...

For single player and some CO-OP modes, or if your a relaxed player, I would recommend this game but there is some other issues I will mention later.

-----Single-Player-----
Pros
Is fun, for the most part.
Guns automatically aim for you, so you don't have to worry if your aim is a potato.
First-time experience is quite the adventure.
You can create helicopters, planes, hovercraft and tanks or other wacky gizmos.
Crafting can be a useful mechanic if used properly.
Money farms can be created to exploit the powers of capitalism.

Cons
Auto-miners automatically stop mining when the player is too far away for some reason.
A.I. Cannot fly planes.
Missions can be repetitive at times.
-----Multi-Player-----
Pros
For most modes you don't need to have friends, although I would recommend though before playing CO-OP Campaign as griefing is a possibility from other players.
Multiplayer combat modes such as death-match.
CO-OP Creative allows you to show-off your builds or to battle with other players with-out restrictions like in sumo or death-match.

Cons
The multiplayer campaign feels somewhat incomplete compared to the single-player campaign, due to fact that all crafting blocks are gone it's significantly more difficult to get higher tier blocks, and to make money as well which in return makes those blocks requires even more grinding to get those blocks to begin with.

Notable
The range for most guns is terrible for dog fights
Lag should not be a surprise
I don't recommend building a large tech in CO-OP as if the host leaves, you would lose all your progress on building that tech.
 -----Other-----
Graphics are decent
Soundtrack is good
Mods are available on the steam workshop.
Community makes some wild techs.
-----Recommendations for Developers-----
Terrain could use some water (Oceans & lakes)
New biomes would enhance the exploration aspect of the game (Mountains, canyons, etc.)
Fix some issues with the multiplayer

Note that I might edit this eventually, either to fix grammar errors or add or remove things which will be highlighted with asterisks.

Steam has no neutral rating, but imagine this is one.

It's pretty fun for the most part, building different techs and fighting enemies, especially from a creative standpoint (think messing around with the creators in Spore as opposed to playing through the actual stages over and over again). Personally I came to this game due to its comparisons to Robocraft, as I wanted to play a good game with similar vehicle building aspects. I'd recommend buying it on sale if it seems like your thing, unless you'd buy it for the multiplayer. That has issues.

I had a good time with it for 40-ish hours just playing the campaign so I think I got my money's worth (bought it 40% off on a sale) but there are a good number of issues with the game to watch out for.

[h1] Campaign Mode [/h1]
The world itself is pretty barren. There are 5 normal biomes (plus 1 rare one), filled with trees, rocks, resource nodes and trading stations. There are a few 'landmarks' as well but they're inconsequential. Enemies can be found standing completely still until you get close enough, or they can drop down from the sky. And that's really it. Obstacles, shops and enemies. 

So what is there to do in the campaign? Fight techs to take their parts (if they have anything worth taking, that is), finish missions for more parts, as well as to unlock new corporations and parts when you 'level up' your licence for a corporation, and harvest resources for money and crafting. Now, there are a few mission series that are relatively interesting and spawn unique buldings/locations (destroy a tech with high defenses in 20 seconds, buy a plane and destroy 3 turrets with your bomb, etc.), but most of them are pretty generic and boring, like 'destroy 300 rocks', 'find a crate nearby and kill 3 enemies that spawned', 'go through this race track fast enough'. Overall, the world feels pretty empty and aside from a short supply of decent quests it's just a grind for more parts so you could do the best part of the game, the building.

[h1] Enemies [/h1]
While at the start it's fun to unlock new parts and upgrading your techs or build new ones, it becomes very repetitive after a while. You aren't really pushed to become stronger aside from your own desire to get new parts and make cooler techs, as enemies are scaled to your current tech's value as a maximum (but you can still find a lot of earlygame enemies later on). The generally weak enemies combined with the dumb as rocks AI make most combat encounters very easy, especially once you've learned how to make better techs or found some decent blocks. 

You are rarely going to find anything that could give you a challenge past the early game, aside perhaps from the occasional 'invader' (rare, stronger enemies uploaded by other players. you gotta use the twitter integration to share your own, which also uses up that tech), though I haven't had any trouble with those past the first few. if you're lucky, an invader might have weapons that you can't buy yet, which makes fighting them a bit more rewarding, but you can easily just skip them because they will just claim a small area and will only attack you if you stay there for too long. 

There are currently no flying enemies in the game either, which limits the enemy variety to different cars and tanks only. It's nice that enemies will fight each other instead of ganging up on you at least, though it does make battles easier still. 

[h1] Resources and Bases [/h1]
TerraTech allows you to build bases using 'anchor blocks' that let you make stationary structures (or temporarily plant your moving tech into the ground to use parts that only work while anchored). Using various conveyor belts, silos, resource collectors and filters, you can build factories that can refine resources, create components and craft various parts for your techs, as well as sell those resources for money. The main benefit of crafting is that it is not limited by licence levels, allowing you to obtain parts you couldn't normally buy or get as quest rewards. 

That said, building a permanent base it's kinda pointless, as you can make 'snapshots' of any tech with a pilot cab attached, so you can just carry them around and rebuild them whenever as long as you got the parts. The stored resources won't go with them, but you can easily craft resource blocks that you can store in your inventory, as well as get more resources and components from putting parts from your inventory (like one of your 100s of obsolete weapons, if you're like me and collect all dropped blocks after a fight) into a scrapper. Because of this, harvesting resources and running around to deliver them to a base feels kinda pointless. I made a mobile base, a proper armed mining vehicle with a factory on its back, but soon realized that there's no point in going in circles to get the right resources when I can just use a scrapper or buy resource blocks instead. You might as well find a spot with a few seams of a more valuable resource, put an autominer on each and place down a small base made of a refinery and a resource seller and AFK for a while, then use the money to buy what you actually need.

Permanent bases are also just less safe than snapshots, since enemies might actually attack them. Enemies don't move if you're far enough away from them, and they don't spawn close to you, so as long as you stay in one place (such as when you put down a base to do something and stay next to it), it's very unlikely that anything will actually attack you, or the base.

[h1] Building and Parts [/h1]
Building techs is the best part of the game, due to the variety of vehicles you can make. Cars, tanks, planes, helicopters and hovercraft are all options, and all the corporations have their own identity and building focus. At first vehicles are very blocky but you can make much better looking ones later on with sloped and corner blocks and stuff. Proper flying techs can be a bit hard to make but it's pretty rewarding when you get them working (though they make the campaign even easier due to the lack of flying enemies but at that point who cares). One annoying thing is that if a part of your tech gets destroyed, it's going to stay destroyed. You will have to load up a snapshot of your tech if you got enough spare parts. You're going to want to have shields and repair bubbles to keep your tech safe but if you lose a more valuable part, or one that you can't buy yet, then you're out of luck.

I'd be surprised if anyone actually read this far cause of how much I'm rambling, but yeah, it's a decent game if you just want to build stuff in creative mode or something but pretty barren and repetitive otherwise. Buy it on sale if you want, but it's not really worth full price, especially given how stagnant development seems to have gotten. They keep adding new parts every once in a while but from what I've heard they have been promising updates to the AI and multiplayer for years now but haven't significantly improved the gameplay in quite a bit, so don't expect too much updates-wise.

A fun game to begin with, from how you can just easily make varied machines and defeat others in order to earn the new and old parts to further your progression. There's also missions which they feel rewarding if you get the new parts from completing them, and taking care in defeating the enemies to get the most parts out of them.

As you move from that particular gameplay loop, the issues of the game begin to show up which unfortunately results in a underwhelming game that feels frustrating and lacking in what it could've been.

The whole mining element and manufacturing feels like it wasn't really properly thought out that would fit the game's direction at least compared to the games like Factorio which feature complex but easily navigable mechanics that don't feel cumbersome. This game takes on a more cumbersome approach with it instead. In order to get the materials, you either have the two options which are to destroy the resource nodes and then bring back to your base or on the spot, depending on your tech's build. This would be fine for early game, however it ends up being the constant as a lot of materials can't be mined, which could be providing you a passive way of gaining the materials or earning money from it.

The other thing is you can mine the "underground" resource nodes, but depending the model of your miner. It can be extremely finicky, especially on more steep inclines that results you in spending minutes in trying to get the machine to properly detect what's below it which really adds up the cumbersome feeling. To make things worse, you end up having to spend some fair amount of time in trying to construct Conveyor belts to connect multiple mining units, in which it feels like a extremely arduous task to do due to how small these components are. And there's no vector-like node system or automation system for making resource transportation easier, resulting in a lot of the elements being done by the player. Another issue is that the miners WILL stop producing money if the player is too far away from the miners due to the chunk loading system.

The manufacturing part feels like it was tacked on and having no reason to exist at all when you could easily buy the parts or get the parts from enemies. And there's not much of a invective to get the resources since a lot of resources are usually often located far away from each other, and the lack of a proper inventory system like the part inventory that you have. So a lot of the times, you'll never find a need for doing that because the systems for that don't really exist that makes it efficient for the player.

The transportation in this game feels quite tedious and rather inefficient, despite just how much you constantly move around. A lot of times, I did find myself having to switch between the vehicles to get around faster but no options for switching between vehicles at different spots that are far away from each other. And there seems to be a jarring lack of rail and water based transport options too.

Which brings me to another point is how little variation the terrain can get. There's not really much of mountains, or even water features that makes the exploration more interesting. A lot of the terrain that I kept seeing are the same repetitive noise-based biome generation that barely reaches above a certain depth and height, which is quite frankly really boring. And not to mention the fact that it can easily get quite frustrating to move around due to how frequently bumpy it is for certain Techs with little variation in between that lends for more natural looking terrain.

Would I recommend this game? Well it really depends on what you want out of this game. But for me, I was hoping that this would be more akin of Factorio with much more fleshed out resource gathering and production mechanics. Even then, it still feels like it hasn't escaped out of Early Access. At this point, it seriously needs a proper sequel that functions as a complete rework of entire game.

Nice game. If you liked Lego you'll like this. Idea is similar - grab some blocks and build what your imagination lets you. But here your vehicles, hovers, planes can finally drive, fly and shoot. Some issues are present sure.

My personal pros and cons list:
Pros:
- Build your own creation as you like it. From more common tanks to sci-fi hovers and even flying saucers. Whatever floats your boat.
- Play camapaign to craft, scavenge and grow your tech from a small trolley to mighty war beast. Or start creative mode and build whatever you like without limitations.
- You can build several techs and put them under control of A.I. to help you in fight. Or build stationary defence tower to guard your mining operations.
- Lot of pew pew action.
- No bugs were encountered so far. 

Cons:
- No manual aim. Press space bar and your tech will fire all guns at once with rather poor auto aim. I can't understand the decision to make such system. Fortunately there is a nice community-made mod "Weapons group" which enables assigning different keys to different guns. This makes situation a little better.
- Explosions. Blast wave punches through everything - neither energy shield nor armor can stop it. It's not uncommon to see your heavily armored tech explode from the inside despite having almost full shield, all because the blast wave was large enough to destroy the batteries protected by several layers of armor. This forces me to build techs capable of destroying hostiles as soon as I see them. Thus all my techs are inevitably ending up as variations of homing missile carriers. Yes, once you get access to missiles you can throw all those machine guns, cannons, lasers right into scrapper. All you need is Hawkeye's cruise missiles - slap 5 of those on any vehicle and it's one shot kill in 99% of cases thanks to the high precision of missiles and the way of how blast wave works. Very fun at first, but it gets old pretty fast.

The game overall is quite good, build your own tech and smash others, while also having a decent, and easy to understand crafting system.
Early game is mostly driving around as a living scrap heap, moving from mission to mission, every fight giving you parts essential to forwarding your survival
Midgame is unlocking the later factions, and building up specific techs to do certain jobs, like harvesting and fighting.
Endgame is where the game loses a bit of steam though, after you complete every mission, and building all the techs you want with the parts you have amassed from countless enemy techs destroyed. you wander the open world looking at the different biomes as you fly or drive over the terrain in you favorite tech.
As in terms of replayability, it all depends on you, and what you want to do in the game, same goes for all building/ survival games, there is no "complete" only the point where you feel accomplished enough to be happy.

Meh. I do recommend this, but only if you understand what it is, and what it isn't. My total time in the game isn't reflected here (much was offline), but here's the short of it:
- combat: meh. Not sophisticated. Perhaps on purpose.
- missions: simplistic. Perhaps on purpose.
- user interface: meh. Some basic things missing (for example I couldn't find a quick way to disassemble a "tech". So if it has 48 pieces, it takes forever removing each piece). Some good, though, the building itself doesn't take long to learn
I can see some people getting really into it, into building bizarre contraptions for example. But it's not really enough for me. 
Again, good for what you get. May not be for you.

NOTES:
This game is a good game and it's quite addicting. The only issues I have with the game is locked content in multiplayer, and the mass amounts of bugs. Audio cuts out, techs rubber band, and the game is very very poorly optimized. In both multiplayer and single player you can't go over 50% render distance without 0% quality, (I personally have an i7 7800X with an RTX 2070) and I can barely get 30 frames with any increase in quality. Also the fact that everyone needs to stick together to go anywhere if one person goes afk or is farming money the entire game comes to a grinding halt. The distance you can travel without a person moving is similar to ARK multiplayer.

TL:DR: 
The game is not the greatest with many bugs, and poor optimization, especially in multiplayer. SO IF YOUR LOOKING FOR A MULTIPLAYER EXPERIENCE LOOK ELSEWHERE.

An amazing game that delivers fun and exciting combat and challenges, while igniting creativity and strategic thinking in the player. Out of the specific robot/vehicle creation games out there, this one is by far the most impressive when it comes to customization and imagination. Hundreds of blocks, tools, weapons, and fun accessories to liven up your vehicle. A well thought out progression system with selectable missions from computers placed around the map. Terra-tech also provides an interesting take on multiplayer combat modes that appeals to the player that prefers the more combat heavy experiences in the main campaign.

9/10 - Hours of fun and creativity inspiring game play

I bought this game a couple of years ago during a steam sale. Even when it was buggy as absolute hell, I loved it. Every update corrupted a save, but added so many more new optimizations and items that I couldn't care less.

Fast forward to now, the game is super polished, fun, and even the unstable version is fairly stable. I haven't lost a world in a long time, and the one I did lose was somehow saved by another update. 

The devs for this game work EXTREMELY hard to pump out a good game whilst making their community happy. Early Access on Steam has been getting loads of crap due to some shoddy devs shafting users out of their money on empty promises, but the TerraTech team should be seen as the gold standard for Early Access Devs.

As for performance, you won't get far on the max settings before your computer begs to be mercy killed with a flaming axe, but the 2 graphics settings below Fantastic look just as great, and will spare your computer. The gameplay is based around an ever-growing tech you build from literally the remains of those who dared to face you. The first couple of hours are essentially the same, kill things, make your bot strong enough to take on the Liscense Boss, and so on, but after that gets out of the way, the world becomes yours to explore, die in, fly in, and dirty up to your hearts content.



Buy it.

Edit: Over a year later, the content updates only get better, and the game is looking better than ever. They've also been hard at work implementing storage solutions to help cut down on lag. I'd recommend this game twice over at this point in time. 

Edit Edit: Items and features are being added even faster... Beta Branch for life

Edit Cubed: Still holds up, and by god have they added a lot of toys.....

This game is amazing for single player. By far, one of the best sandbox pve games. The devs eventually added a co-op campaign mode, which made the game amazing, and I assumed they would make it fully like the single player mode, so you can craft items instead of relying on rng to gather anything. They didn't. In fact, more than 6 months have gone by since co-op campaign has come out and absolutely no updates have been done to it. I understand wanting to improve the main game, but there was already tons of stuff. The devs, as far as I can tell, have completely abandoned  the co-op campaign, and this game gets boring really fast when you play by yourself. 
Update: It's been more than 2 years now I think. Co-op is untouched other than minor bug fixes and language support. If you even slightly think you'd want a game you can play with friends this isn't it.

Games like these get me all the time. They have near endless possibilities and creativity and Terra Tech is no exception.

It has more than just build a thing and do a thing, it has quests, story, economy, and combat. Each mechanic is handled well and changes up the pace when you need it. The bright graphics give it charm and sets a good tone imo. Im always striving for a better and better build and this game makes that easy and manageable while providing plenty of options and build choices. 

The only things that bother me is sometimes there is strange visual issues (black squares pop up sometimes) and the flying mechanics need some tweaking. Other than that, this game is worth the time if you like to build things and hit a niche spot that you cant find in other titles.

IF you want a [b]sandbox/creative[/b] vehicles building game with an arena to fight against other player's techs, [b]buy this game[/b]. It is in my opinion one of the best games in this genre out there.


IF you want a [b]survival[/b] game with [b]base building[/b], resource collection and manufacturing, then [b]don't buy this game[/b].


In my opinion 50% of the survival mechanics are broken. Let me explain why:

Basically in this game you can collect resources, process them and then either sell the products or manufacture blocks from them, which you can use to add to your tech.
But setting up a base is not only tedious but also aside from charging your tech pretty much useless, because of [b]bugs[/b] that are around [b]since Early Access[/b].

Especially the placing of conveyor belts is unusable, because it randomly auto-connects to adjacent conveyor belts and then you have to remove and place them again and again hoping they finally form the line you want.

And when you finally finished your base and think you can let it produce the stuff you need and go resource collecting. Then if you went out too far and come back to your base, it greets with your fabricators being stuck, so all you can do is cancel the production, which will make you lose all the already consumed components and start it again every time.
And that all because of a bug that is around since Early Access. So don't get your hopes up, that it will ever be fixed. (Yes, I reported it multiple times and had even devs reply, that it's a known bug...)

Ohh and theoretically there is an AI that can help you collect resources, but basically only if they are right next to your base, on flat terrain and you also stay, so it stays loaded.


So all you can do is fight bots, steal their blocks and complete some quests.

I do love and enjoy my sandbox games and this one I can't pass up. 

you start off by having something that's basically a go cart with a laser on top. Just like or similar to the fish ya get a few kills and salvage the leftover parts to build on to your own rig. Getting bigger and stronger as you  go. Of course there are other ways to be able to improve and grow. One of which is to be able to craft and salvage the basic parts and materials in order to make bigger/faster/Badder stuff. Depending if you unlocked the blueprints and tech needed for the building of all that cool stuff. As you can tell from the trailers the different "corps" as their called has their own set of focus and tech. With one focusing on getting the raw goodies  with extra large everything from drills, pile drivers, and Saws. While another corp would focus on the military tech. Like the kind of stuff you would see War Machine would sport from Iron Man. 

had some near close calls in the game where I nearly got wiped out but just barely held on if it wasn't for a fair amount of luck and quick grabbing anything I could. Overall a good game for those custom made vehicle builders sandbox game.
Pretty cool game, easyer than most other vehicle bulding games like trailmakers and scrap mechanic, but with pretty cool combat.

while also allowing you to test and see how effective certain designs and machines are to make life easier in survival.

In terms of a creativity-toy, it's an interesting one for sure. The Building is fairly intuitive and what few tutorials you need are easy to understand.

The vehecles handle differently based on how you build them and you soon develop an understanding of how something will most likely handle before you drive it.

Combat is... basic. Some fun weapons in the later game, but it really only comes alive in multiplayer. Not that it wouldn't work in Singleplayer, but the AI is very simple. They chase you head on, rarely try to flank or outmaneuver you, making for functional but boring combat. Even enemies that vastly overgear your own vehicle can usually be beaten by using the AI to your advantage.

Story: doesn't exist.

Quests: randomly generated Gather- and Killquests aside, 90% are tutorials. The Timetrial races and a handfull of other handcrafted quests are well done and implemented though.

Crafting: Weirdly involved for how simple the rest of the game is. Not unintuitive, just... involved. And completely ignorable, due to the ability to buy every part available from shops.

Graphics: They do the job. Stylized and simple, but not ugly. Nothing feels out of place and it's overall very cohesive.

Biggest personal gripe: No "Endgame". The game could have done well with something, ANYTHING to do. A goal to work towards, Bosses to destroy, Maybe play up the rivalry between the companies. As it stands, you are thrown into a world, guided to the different Tutorials, establish a base and that's where the game ends. The second you have a stable and secure production set up, the game looses all sense of challenge and danger. Hence the reliance on Multiplayer.

Bugs: I came across very few. The occasional quest that gets stuck but even that hasn't occured for quite a while.

Verdict: 6/10. Very good foundation to build a game onto. Amazingly easy to understand and intuitive to use Building system to support a game that isn't there.
Fun, but a missed opportunity.

TL;DR: mixed review. Good music, promising gameplay, but a little too hand-holdy and the exploration isn't all that worth it.

I wish I could put "mixed" as an option for rating. It's got great upsides for what it's aiming for, but in its current state it also has places where it falls short.

The pros:
- The concept of building your craft makes for a great time. Want to be something out of Mad Max? You can do that. Want to be a B-17? Go ahead. Ever thought of being a giant box of armor plating and nothing else? I mean, no one's stopping you. Seeing it in action, though, is what makes it great.
- The western-esque soundtrack compliments the game nicely. Driving through a vibrant alien world can still have some earthy feel to it.
- Achievements exist for skill, mostly. There's one called "David and Goliath" in which you take down a bigger tech with a much smaller one, just to name one of many.
- Base building! If you ever have come from Factorio, it's not as advanced but there are some similar cross-overs to resource processing and trying not to make jams.
- Resource management is pretty okay. Shiny metals await you out there.

Cons:
- There isn't really much to explore. The world is procedural, sure, but aside from random tech spawns and small trade outposts, there's not much else you can find outside of missions.
- Most missions contrast with the open worldliness of this game. It holds your hand and most, if not all, main missions from GeoCorp are uninteresting grind quests (collect 50 wood, mine 200 of this ore, etc) with no change later on.
- Missions are the only way to progress in purchasing higher-tier gear, as some blocks require license upgrades to buy. While this system itself isn't wrong, the associated missions could be refined.
- Enemy tech frequency is frustrating. You will always come across one, but despite its chance of running away from you, most if not all will try to engage in combat. It doesn't feel fun when it constantly happens and the game doesn't give you much of a breather to cool down.

Terratech is definitely the only game of its type on the market, as far as gameplay goes. It has a ton of pros due to this, but has some pretty hefty cons to boot. Over-all, I would suggest this game to anyone that loves being creative, engineering, or has some level of "Battlebots" fandom. The game consists of a very basic, survival style vehicle building game until later on when more and more advanced parts are discovered or developed, leading to very intricate, or very basic and brutal vehicle designs. However, players may feel lost after completely unlocking all parts in the game, leading to a very open and very empty sandbox. There is boundless opportunity to be creative in this game; however, creativity will become your major limit.

Pros:
+One of the best physics, vehicle-building, and construction engines I have ever played.
+Tons of style and flash, from unique corporations that offer different weapons, weighted blocks, and cool devices to change how your vehicles work.
+Literally no limit to what you build, other than how large it can be (and even its maximum size can be absolutely massive). Structures, airplanes, anti-gravity vehicles, tanks, cars, hovercraft, or all of the above.
+A beautiful and basic asthetic that looks really good under any conditions.
+Amusing characters and hilarious item descriptions.

Cons:
-No real endgame with a complete lack of anything to do as far as objectives at the end. There are repeatable missions at the mission stations, but they offer very little in the way of unique encounters or fun scenarios. After maybe 10 or a little more, you quickly notice there's nothing really new to do.
-Manufacturing can be unintuitive, extremely complex, and just bug out, leading to frustratingly long endeavors.
-Enemy vehicles spawned into the game can range from oppressive to absolutely meaningless, seeming to scale from area instead of vehicle piloted. This means that driving around a scout vehicle can lead to some obscene challenges, but riding around in a massive weapon platforms just makes every engagement meaningless.
-Missiles are far too powerful and the ways to defend against them are far too inefficient, causing even the smallest of engagements to suddenly end your situation.
-Outside of 5 biomes, there's nothing really new to discover. The world is very large and very empty. Don't expect to roam around and find an enemy base with a challenging layout and fun guards defending it, because the most you'll get is a tree, or the occasional enemy player tech spawn that dies after one slew of missile barrages.
-A bug that caused one of the aforementioned enemy player tech spawns ("Invaders") spawned mine underground, forcing my game to never spawn another invader again, leaving me with aforementioned trivial enemy techs to fight.
-Co-op is extremely unrefined, may never be coded properly due to the game's complexity, and has limited features. Don't expect to build a base and siege other player's bases, because the required coding to do that would probably take an entire AAA studio, and they're busy making games that aren't fun and just grab your money fast.

Pretty fun and creative game. Plays a little similarly to actually quite a few games I’ve played, and was also one of the first games I ever owned on steam. If you like Scrap Mechanic/Trailmakers, some elements of Factorio, and games where you make vehicles fight with guns and bombs and stuff (such as Besiege), then this could be for you!

You start off with a tiny little block that represents your core, with 6 points of attachment, one for each side. You can attach more blocks to your core until you’ve got a nice looking frame, then add as many wheels, treads, wings, propellers, or rockets as you like for movement. After that, you can add special pieces that emit forcefields and healing zones. These run on power, so you also need to add some battery blocks. To charge the battery blocks, you’ll need to set up a base, with an anchor-block as a core. You can put some solar panels on this to generate electricity, and then put your batteries on the base, and now you have forcefields on your vehicle. Next we add weapons. There’s all sorts of weapons. We’ve got Machine guns, Lasers, Spears, Explosive cannons, Mortars, Drills, Shotguns, Homing-Rockets, and more. With these weapons you can kill off other AI-controlled vehicles, and then steal their stuff. Then you can sell their stuff for money, or just keep it for yourself. With money, you can buy whatever you want.

Back to the base, you can also add automatic mining machines, shields on your base, refineries, conveyor belts, storage silos, resource sellers, and more. With the use of crafting, you can also make your own stuff without killing other vehicles or selling things for money. 

Overall, the game is pretty fun, but it is kind of eh, pointless almost? While there is absolutely progression, there’s not really a goal or story to the game, and enemy vehicles eventually stop getting better once you get to a point where you’re just super overpowered. Don’t get me wrong in this paragraph though, I’m not saying the game is pointless to play, but before you buy, know that there’s technically not anything to work towards except trying to have a super powerful base and/or vehicle.

Pros: 

1. Campaign has a simple but fun system. You mine and drill and refine and build your own machine. 
2. You can build ships, ground vehicles, airplanes, and mobile bases with default control scheme. 
3. Build tool is simple and easy to learn. 
4. Control is simple with auto aiming 
5. It's like a RoboCraft that supports singleplayer. 

Cons: 

1. You cannot build a Mech, (Gundam, MS,  Walker, Titan, whatever you called it.)  There's no walker parts and trying to make one yourself will be difficult and ugly. 
2. You cannot make custom movable parts, like a turning turret that made of blocks and mounts all the smaller guns. 
3. Control is simple but lacks detail configuration like firing in sequence or firing at different target, there's no firing arc indicator either. 
4. Singleplayer Campaign is rather empty, given a funny system. 
5. Very few ppl online.

If the game has walker parts (Bipedal, quadrupedal, whatever), it will be the ideal game I've been looking for forever. Right now it's like a 8/10.

As of the time of this review this game has a lot of problems.
Yes its very simple, yes the A.I. is trash, both friendly and enemy, yes you are attacked while in the middle of building stuff, but those actually arn't my gripes with it.

My problem with this game is how many of the available parts really just don't work, and it always seems to be the interesting ones.

You have all the parts for a helicopter, but good luck building one that actually works. You have hovercraft parts, but without exploiting accidental bugs good luck building one that isn't a piece of shit. I mean for a game about building fun machines out of available parts, it sure doesn't feel like the devs tested any of this shit to see if it actually works. And it's been like this for years so it isn't going to change.

Also I do have a problem with the draw distance. The response for why it's so short is something something CPU requirements, but honestly I don't buy it.

Honestly have no idea why the hell this has such good ratings. The basis of a good game is there, but the development is so basic its unreal. There are bugs littered through out the game, and we arent talking elaborate bugs, we are talking things like turrets shooting at friendly targets, production buildings not pulling from base inventory etc etc. Now one might thing its because the game is still early days, and that is true to a point. But before you use that excuse, bare in mind, the devs literally had basic features as providing a map as part of their short term goals in 2018. Its now 3 days away from Q4 2021 and still to sign of it. Either the devs are in over their heads, or they aren't putting in the effort they should for bug fixing and basic quality of life fixes.

I hope these issues get fixed, i really really do, because as i said, the basis of a good game is there, but players should not be expected to find work around for bugs that haven't been fixed for, according to the community pages, years.

I might review again at some point in the future, but as of Q4 2021, its a no from me. Hopefully the game gets to a state in the future where i change that opinion.

The game seemed to have a decent amount of content. Several factions each with unique technologies and a "ok" building system. So me and my friends all bought the game to play together, and we did, until we realized that we had been "scammed" by the developers. And I wish I hadn't had to use harsher words, but just read the description of the game in Steam:
"Team up with other intrepid prospectors in Co-op Campaign, ...."

It doesn't say that it's not complete, or not the same as single. So after looking like an ass with all my 4 friends who bought the game because I recommended, I still had some hopes that it was a work in progress. Patch in, patch out, and no progress except adding more blocks, many of them purely cosmetic in my opinion, since they are Unity objects with texture and collision boxes, and no actual logic in to them.

</end rant>

No, I do not recommend anyone to purchase this game, ESPECIALLY if you want to play Coop. If the devs ever redeem themselves, I'll gladly change my review, but at this point, I have no hopes that this will ever happen.

The game itself is fun, but the support is non-existent. On my computer, the controllers do not work. Once you are in the air, the game is barely playable without an analog axis. I have asked for help on the official forums and on the Steam hub and never received any response, neither from the community nor from the developer. This is the only game that has a problem with controllers on my computer.

Edit:
I have found the cause of the problem: I am using a keyboard with analog keys (Roccat ISKU Force FX) which is stored by Windows as Game Device 0 - i.e. as the first game device. All other controllers have a higher number. It seems that Terratech only supports the first game device. The pop up dialog for remapping controllers at game start does not work (nothing happens when I move a stick to remap the axis). A remedy is to start the computer with a different keyboard. But since this is very inconvenient and I did not receive any support from the developer, I still give it a thumbs down.

So, I used to have a positive review. However, returning to the game to find the same problems I had with it in late 2015...Yeah, not going to fly with me. Major problem as of right now, is that in early game the player is given NO TIME to breath; ever. You can't stop and build for a minute or enemies will wiggle-wander closer to you until they're within aggro range and...well, there goes 30+ minutes of progress as you get shredded while you were working on an incomplete design :)

And R&D is only so useful for designing, because you can't easily cross reference how many of what you had when you closed the campaign to go to R&D to attempt to side-step this issue.

I'd say spawns probably could do with being pushed away a little more for early game enemies, they do tend to spawn far too close to the player due to their reduced size. And while they are theoretically weak...it's hard to fight when it's endless combat for 20 minutes. Enemy wander AI could maybe also be taught to be patient, and not wiggle closer to the player if it's idle and within AI processing range as well. Could also help if there was an options-menu toggle to show aggro range on the map

Finally, the last gripe I have with campaign: Restriction of the SCU to far too late in the game? Trade station SCUs only help so much, and cobbling everything dumped on you onto an anchor takes precious time...time the game spends spawning more problems for you. Personally I just think the SCU should be starter gear, or given at the first visit to a trade station. It's integral gear that the player should become familiar with early on anyway, I don't see why it's held behind missions for so long, other than artificially dragging out the early game.

for the price to have gone up to what it has, and still have the same bugs and balance issues as 6+ years ago, is honestly insulting to players.

The computer version of this game is awesome, the xbox version is terrible. less content and theres a limit block, that being said do to the content on the computer they created flaws.
-the main one being the flying. there's no such thing as perfect balance. your plane will always go up or down, no matter what you do the thrust vs center of gravity is off regardless. I like the science behind air dynamics that being said, I played alot of kerby space program, I decided to experiment, see about getting the fastest plane possible, i managed to create one that almost hit the sound barrier, 1125 mph, problem is that without the option to center it, it wobbled all over the place going in a straight line. the wings contracted and extracted like a musical instrument or something. that being said, your plane speed is hard capped somewhere do to the physics in this game. you really cant make a plane that does above 120 mph without running into glitches somewhere.
-the 2nd biggest issue is the spawning with the planes. I wanted run around fighting but the spawning radius is so small that you rarely see anything once you hit the sky. so you build this high tech killing machine and kill one or two enemies. that's it, the plane is really only good for going from point a to point B. On the other hand, you make a standard vehicle and try going from point a to b and enemies are everywhere. air combat is more or less eliminated by the lack of enemy spawns.
3rd issue I would have to say is its a sandbox game without sandbox options. Want more enemy spawns, I like fighting, Want to feel like Im surviving rather then the enemies are just an annoyance while i'm trying to build then gone when im fighting. higher yields, in the late game equipment is insanely expensive it seems out of balance.
- I hate the collision damage, because there's not much you can do about it. you build a highly efficient harvester then try to drive at full speed, you are losing random pieces just from bumps on the ground that you can't even see.
the 5th biggest I would have to say is the combination of unrealism vs realism. they add physics, mass vs speed, etc, so you build a big ship and your vehicle slows down, makes sense, but then you can't add more engines, more tires won't do anything. if you choose to scrap enemy vehicles, you put this big magnet on the back of your vehicles, not realistic, but cool, but then the physics are there, so as you collect parts your vehicle is weighed down and you start dragging it across the ground and its chipped away in pieces, or when the enemy attacks you blow up your own pieces. the only real option you have is to port in the teleport system, send your parts to inventory, then despawn it, over and over again.
 -Despite how much I personally like this game I would not be able to recommend it to a friend because there are too many core issues that I can find a way to work around but an inexperianced player could not. they wouldn't understand why their vehicle is being destroyed just from driving at full speed. they would not understand why their plane doesn't seem to work right regardless, and the game doesn't seem complete. the helicopters are advertised but try driving one. you can't build a heavily armored vehicles because without the ability to up the performance thru engines or some other means, it won't drive.
-The tires are an enormous issue. tank treads aren't supposed to get stuck, bottom line, yet most the time they cant even make it up hill.

the game is pretty fun and spending time on making a cool tech and fighting with it is a unique feeling that you don't get in many games, which makes this game very special. however, there are two main flaws in a game like this.
exploring is pretty pointless, after playing for a bit, the only reason you would explore is to find the different biomes and that's it. the terrain and structures can be cool, but that feeling of fascination doesn't last long. perhaps the chance to find extremely strong techs or some other reward for exploring would make this game a lot more fun.

the other major flaw would be how slow the game can be sometimes. i mean literally, with the blocks you get, you're practically forced to have slow and bulky techs with lots of batteries and giant wheels. i think that having some way to give small speedy, even close range, techs a niche would also improve the game. (maybe being able to dodge would be a way to make glass-cannon-type techs viable? right now it's sort of hard to dodge due to explosives and how venture is the only faction focused on speed)
also, a few of the factions are sectioned off for late game which kinda sucks. you're forced with gso and geo-corp-two factions that reward slow and bulky techs. i think variety is extremely important for more replay ability and enjoyment. 
slow and bulky techs are fun for the first few times you play but being stuck with them early to mid game is boring. with the way the terrain is, slow and bulky techs are discouraged even more. i want to be able to have a fast tech that can also beat other techs. some way to make the pve more skill based would be great because right now, it's just run into a tech and hold down space. improving the pve would make the game a lot more fun because i think the two most fun parts about terratech is the creative aspect and the pve aspect.

This game is alot of fun alone. You get to pilot your "tech" and as you destroy ennemies, you loot their parts to upgrade yourself. It is extremly satisfying and rewarding. As you play you will eventually gain access to refining and crafting wich, while not being that much fun, give you something new to do. It give you a reason to build bigger.

Now the negative side of things.
I bought this game to play with my brother as it said it was Co-op, wich is a complete lie.
Yes my brother can join my game and have his own tech.
Yes he can help me do missions and defeat ennemies.
But!
He does not have his own inventory or money. He must use my stuff and is tethered to me like ark used to do in early access. The crafting has been completely remove from Co-op mode, wich removes the purpose of making bases.

Basically, what the devs call Co-op is basically just a player taking control of one of your AI vehicles and following you around the same way and AI would.

People asked the devs to fix those issues and the devs said it would be impossible to make Co-op work otherwise, wich is just a way of saying theyre too lazy to do it.

So overall, the game is AMAZING if you like playing ALONE but is it NOT Co-op.

Edit: After playing 200 more hours, Here is what i have to say.
1. The game is amazingly addictive.
2. There is alot more content in the solo campain than there is in the coop one.
3. Despite my second point, the game is alot more fun in coop.
4. This game is a bug simulator and the dev is more concerned with adding more block than he is with fixing the darn thing.

So overall, i maintain my negative review because in its state, the game is not worth buying at full price and the dev dont seem to care or be competent enuff to fix it.

To the dev: Dont take it the wrong way, your game could be a best seller if you gave it the love it needs instead of focusing all your ressources into adding more buggy things to it.

Really neat game, I love it so much, the sandbox shinanigans and the customization you can do in it is incredible. One problem with it is the combat is unnaturally infuriating. The weapons try to auto aim, but they always end up either missing or hitting parts that you want to keep, destroying them and frustrating you. Not to mention that every single time you're in combat, the enemy flanks behind you. Endlessly. Constantly. And you can't catch them sometimes. They just slowly keep shooting behind you, and you often can't even turn fast enough to hit them, let alone fight back. This leads to a frustrating cycle of trying to shoot them, the guns automatically shooting places you don't WANT them to shoot AT, and being unable to fight techs that you normally would be able to dominate if it wasn't for the fact that the turnspeed is so inconsistant that it leads to immense frustration.

The good is that the building IS. INCREDIBLE. Honestly you can build pretty much ANYTHING in this game. You want a plane? Well guess what there's massive wings. You want a giant hellicarrier for a mechanical marvel reference? Good news there's hovercraft. You want a massive, unstoppable fortress that can withstand any attack that comes at it? Well there are anchor parts, large cannons, mortars, rotaries, shields, solar generators, refineries. Honestly, I have found very few games that can rival this one in sheer amount of customization. Think of it as a better, more mechanized version of Spore. (With a better story, though that bar wasn't that high to begin with.)

Pros:
 +Good vehicle-based combat
    -Not just cars!
 +On-the-fly vehicle editing makes for smooth gameplay
 +Workshop mod support

Cons:
 -Bright environments with a transparent/white minimap makes it hard to navigate sometimes
 -Easy to lose your mouse cursor
 -Difficult to make a working plane/helicopter (but that makes sense because those are both OP as all heck)

Overall:
Great game with surprisingly deep vehicle customization methods. Very addictive too. I think the devs still actively update as well. Most of the cons I listed could be fixed if we just had some more depth in the options menu.

It's pretty fun, but not perfect. The engine works great, the construction and physics are totally solid, which is no small feat in a game like this. I get some audio glitches though, weirdly enough. The game is UNPLAYABLE without the targeting mod, as your guns auto-aim incorrectly and they will miss every single shot if your vehicle is moving laterally. With the targeting mod though every works as it should. I found the campaign to be far too easy, and with too much filler. The vehicle building is also bit too simplistic for my tastes.

Fairly decent game all in all. I've been following up with this game since the VERY early days of early access, and it is amazing what the developers have accomplished.

The game is fairly simple: Build your tech, destroy other techs for parts, build yours bigger, repeat. The game also has different missions to do in the campaign from simple finding dead drops to destroying intricate enemy bases.

Multiplayer is kind of "meh" to me. When they first announced they were adding multiplayer to terratech, I was astounded, and I never knew it could be possible. Unfortunately, even to this day, the multiplayer is quite limited and feels unfinished. The "campaign multiplayer" doesn't have any major manufacturing blocks, and missions are quite limited.

The game still feels unfinished and a little empty. Overall, not a bad game, but not the best in the world.
I can no longer recommend this game. It is consistently frustrating at every turn for a myriad of reasons, and despite how much love I have for it, I just don't think I can play it any more.
