Really fun if you like building vehicles and bases.
The early game is super grindy, but as you unlock more corporations it becomes much more fun. This game has come so far from when I bought it 3 years ago and it is still receiving frequent content updates.

My main problems:
Quests repeat themselves often since many are procedurally generated.
Terrain is bland and a little broken, but that's mainly a limitation of procedural generation.
The game runs pretty horribly, even on my relatively strong system I drop into the 30s in medium sized fights.

Overall, great if you don't care about the quests and just build cool stuff :)

TerraTech is a great vehicle building game, one of the best ones around. In addition to a large selection of parts and possibilities it provides gameplay ranging from calm resource gathering, through exploration of alien biomes to explosive combat. This game is frustating to the point of wanting to break my keyboard (which rarely happens). I'll explain why.

When you're starting out and trying to mind your own business, you're constantly harassed by other techs dropping in, no matter how big or small, every 10 - 60 seconds. They drop in a radius around you, sometimes close, sometimes far. They may be paused/suspended, but the moment you get close, they animate and make a beeline straight for you and your backside. Most of the techs are gunbricks by the time that you've managed to get into the military corporation in this game (who has a vehemently ceaseless, sawdust-huffing hen-swabble of a miserable dosser for your majority of having to put up with this useless pile of scrap, who's best words aren't even memorable to the point of being noteworthy. Not to mention the "agent", who is just as useless, if not even more so as she is a joke within a joke that was left to ferment for over a milennia, it seems. Get with the times and be more useful instead of seeking a kick, moron. - Side note, the military guy finally starts recognizing your potential after a while, but the agent is a waste of time. Least you get to bomb things though.)

The AI is straight garbage, having vehement (there's that word again) problems in navigating even hills or around static objects. You have to babysit the AI every time at the time speaking, they're less than basic, their only pro being that they can even navigate at all, let alone be cannon fodder They don't even stop 1mm away from you and CONSTANTLY TRY TO PUSH YOU AROUND WHILE YOU'RE TRYING TO BUILD OR LOOK AT SOMETHING. D'you know how rile-up-inducing that shit is? I'll give you an idea. When you're at a party (if you've been to one of course, can't speak for everyone, we've had different experiences) and some gangly-haired fuck-knuckle drunkard of a night-time shades-wearing, beach-shirt & crocs douchenozzle with a riced out Corsa/Fiesta comes and keeps shoving you around as you're trying to mind your own business? That's this "buddy" AI. Harvesting AI was removed, so you're better off getting in your big brick of a creation and mining yourself. (to their merit, a Payload employee explained the reason for this, being multiple bases confused them.) Did I mention they were garbage?

Oh, but here's the best part. The enemy AI's don't stop spawning, even when you're trying to FUCKING TIME TRIAL. Even when you're trying to harvest, these insufferable, rat-ash-huffing, smooth-brained oafs will continue spawning, with some downright painful machinery (The first one who really messed up my base was a well-built GeoCorp, yellow guys who harvest better than anyone in the game. My base was well built, with everything I needed, and this prick spawned with a behemoth-sized rig with a powerful shield, multiple guns, and mining machinery and messed it all up.) who then proceed to harass you and try to end your existence in this game for no other reason than you're playing. Trying to complete a mission? Fuck you, have a few enemies, go fuck 'em up boys. Trying to harvest? Oh, no no no no no, we can't have that sir, go fuck yourself. Here's some enemies for you in particular. Trying to build something? Let's surround you with enemies, so when you're done, you can go fuck yourself even harder. Not even exams are this hard for you, why should you have peace or some fun?

And last but not least, some missions require you've grinded enough cash, or even got enough of a juggernaut that you can survive a hailstorm or speed along REAL FAST. The hover trial mission i'm trying to do? AI on the trail + hills = Bad News Barret has come to give you no reach-around.

Honestly this game pisses me off, just let me fucking build in the campaign damnit. And give me a better fucking AI companion who looks where they're going and drives their machines properly if you're going to offer us that option. I'll give you a thumbs up when this shit is solved.

My name is Kira Yoshikage. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

I came to TerraTech by way of other vehicle building games (B-K: N&B, Trailmakers) excited to find another game to scratch my "scavenge parts to make a cool vehicle" itch. TerraTech does a way worse job at this though in my opinion. It seems like all you ever do in TerraTech is complete boring missions that are just "go across the map to this destination while trying not to get killed". The combat is super annoying because there really isn't that much strategy other than "have a lot of guns". The battery charging mechanic is super annoying because it just means you have to stop your progress to recharge every few minutes. The building interface is also super annoying because even my relatively low level car had tons of different parts that were constantly needing to be rearranged/rebuilt when I gained or lost a part. 

So overall, too much of this game felt like management of my vehicle, and the parts that weren't were super annoying and boring. Not the game I was looking for.

The more I want to like this game, the more I am being pushed back by it. So far I don't think I've had a single play session where something wouldn't frustrate me to some extent, so let me put out a couple issues that stood out to me personally.

-Turrets do not lead the target properly. Your vehicle's momentum is added to the projectile's momentum on top of that, meaning that any attempt at making a fast and agile combat vehicle is not viable. All of the fighting I've done so far involve stacking guns on top of guns and carpet bombing the crap out of the entire area in order to try and smash an enemy.
-There are no weapon groups, which renders some weapons entirely useless. Scoops, supposedly capable of flipping an enemy, are activated by the same key as all the other weapons. So either avoid firing at the enemy in an attempt to flip them, or fire at will and see your scoop flailing randomly at a set interval. The same goes for rotatable drills, since you can't lock them in a position that's most suitable.
-There is no way to adjust the difficulty setting as far as I know, which in early game can overwhelm you. I've read that in late game this turns around to the point where there's no challenge, but I'm not really willing to find that out.
-The enemies spawn at a set distance from the player, regardless of anything else. This can make the player be an active threat to their own base, because the enemies can drop right on top of a player's anchored structure and then proceed to obliterate it. So obviously, you want to have all your structures supplied with an AI module and a shitton of guns. But remember bad turret lead?
-There is no map. You have only your memory and a tiny radar minimap to tell you where's what, and where your own structures are. Friendly blips on the minimap will disappear if you go far enough from them, so if you want to revisit a mining base you built you better write down its coordinates in Notepad.
-Production is bugged. If you have a fabricator gathering resources to build a block and move over 500m away from it, the fabricator will never produce the block – even after having the resources gathered. Cancelling the production and ordering another one will not fix this. You have to remove and replace the fabricator.
-Co-op campaign has no crafting, which is a shame – but from what I have gathered is currently in the making – and the trading stations only sell blocks that have been discovered by you or the other players. This renders exploration completely pointless.
-Building, which at first is very intuitive, can become tedious. There's a single key dedicated to rotating blocks. If you have a large block with over 20 attachment points, this will make it a chore to find the one you want, since you have to iterate over all of them.
-Additionally, replacing any block that's buried deep inside your grid can be frustrating, since blocks will want to attach anywhere but the one place you want them to.

And you know what's the most disappointing part about this all? Quick googling can show that a lot of these issues have been known and requested to be added or fixed for years. Don't expect any of that to change soon.

If you want to try this game out, I'd suggest waiting for a major sale and/or a free weekend. But even that might not make all the issues apparent.

Terra Tech is simply a one-of-a-kind game.
Many other games have the same kind of premise, harvest resources and level up (kind of) to get more parts and to make a better, more advanced main vehicle. I used to play a lot of this game on the Xbox One, and the 7000 cpu limit in the CAMPAIGN was awful. I couldn't make more than 3 vehicles! But then, I put 20 dollars into Steam, and out came this masterpiece.

To start, this game on Steam has, and listen to this closely, NO. CPU. LIMIT. Oh my god, if you have a decent pc, this game is amazing. You can build huge bases so big they make you lag just by looking at them, you can create 50 small little swarm techs to overwhelm your enemies, I mean, you can even build a Halo Warthog if you're skilled enough (and have the blocks). The campaign of this game is wonderful, the quests are mostly busy work at the beginning, but as you level up your ranks with the various factions, they get into really fun quests with custom areas. I don't want to spoil too much, as I'd recommend the campaign first.

Okay, and on to the Creative Mode. Creative is, well, creative. You have unlimited of all the blocks, and you can make essentially whatever you want, similarly to the campaign, although creative gives you much more to work with. Obviously.

And finally, the Multiplayer Mode. There are 3 modes of multiplayer, as I recall. Deathmatch, a customizeable mode where you can have fun defeating your friends or randoms online in multiple maps, With multiple sizes of each. Each kill gets you more and more parts, however, if you die, you die. Have fun getting everything back. Next up is the co-op modes. Co-Op Creative and Survival are like survival and creative, but with a few blocks unavailable (I'm guessing because of issues with two people). Overall though, it provides a fun experience despite missing a couple essential blocks.

So, to conclude my essay (I've been typing for 15 minutes), Terra Tech is an open-world, infinitely generated sandbox game, with obviously building mechanics. AIs to kill or ally surround you always, and I've never seen 2 of the same enemy across either Xbox or PC (Despite bosses and quest characters). Overall, Terra Tech is a fun game that provides hours of fun, whether you play solo or with friends. That concludes my recommendation.

(By the way, I've been playing this game for years on Xbox but recently got it on PC, hence the 26 hour playtime. So I know what I'm talking about.)

This game was great, years ago... and has only gotten better!  The campaign mode is exponential.  You start small but every mission and battle gives you more access and more parts.  Before long, you go from a collection of scrap items to huge vehicles and the ability to buy anything.  The maps are generated in such a way that if you ever get bored of your location, you just pick up and move to something better.  Plus, if you ever get tired of single player, there is a multiplayer option; and competition between players.  The PC version is of course, much better since you have less limitations.  But any version of this game is a win.

Its a very simple game. build a rolling fortress and crush your enemies while blotting out the sun with bullets. I bought the game a few years ago and tried it again recently and it has improved so much. it has amusing quests and a satisfying game play loop that guides you without treating you like a child.

The main limit is your own creativity.

Oh yeah protect your command block, if that breaks your whole contraption falls to pieces and then you have to go rescue it from another veritable fortress that will one shot the dinky rover the game gives you when you die.

One problem that i ran into is, when you die, it gives you the option to recreate the vehicle you were using. However, its really easy to inflate the cost of your rover because every enemy you defeat drops a lot of blocks. As such i built my creation from the corpses of my enemies. my early game rover was 10x the cost of the money i was able to make in the early game. This means that i have to either go get my remains or start over.

Fantastic resource gathering, vehicle building, small base building game!  Like most everyone else says, it starts off very slowly.  You will have to transport the parts of the enemy vehicles you destroy back by attaching them to your roof.  Refining and crafting will be nearly non-existent at the beginning.  But within a few hours you will be building your own factory that can launch raw materials off in to space.  But if you refine them, they are worth more!  To refine them efficiency, you could really use some filters and silos, which you can manufacture yourself!

The fighting is nothing to write home about, but it can be difficult at times, and when you crack a big guy open and harvest all of his pieces, it's great!

One thing that made me not buy this game for months was thinking it was creative-only, or that crafting your vehicle was nearly free; like Scrap Mechanic.  That's not the case at all!  You will need to either harvest lots of ores or kill lots of enemies.  You will also have a fairly weak shield, so you might lose quite a bit of your vehicle if you are careless.

If you like crafting and resource-gathering games with a little bit of combat, this game is for you!
